componenttext: Good morning. My name is Regina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Wells Fargo Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Jim Rowe, Director of Investor Relations. Mr. Rowe, you may begin your conference.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Regina, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today, where our Chairman and CEO, John Stumpf; and our CFO, John Shrewsberry will discuss fourth quarter results and answer your questions. This call is being recorded. Befor
componenttext:
Thank you, Regina, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today, where our Chairman and CEO, John Stumpf; and our CFO, John Shrewsberry will discuss fourth quarter results and answer your questions. This call is being recorded. 
Before we get started, I would remind you that our fourth quarter earnings release and quarterly supplement are available on our website at wellsfargo.com. I'd also like to caution you that we may make forward-looking statements during today's call that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from expectations are detailed in our SEC filings, including the Form 8-K filed today containing our earnings release and quarterly supplement. Information about any non-GAAP financial measures referenced, including a reconciliation of those measures to GAAP measures, can also be found in our SEC filings, in the earnings release and the quarterly supplement available on our website. 
I'll now turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, John Stumpf.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, and happy new year. Thank you for joining us today. Our strong performance in 2015 reflected the benefit of our diversified business model and our focus on the real economy. Our contribution to the real economy in 2015 was br
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, and happy new year. Thank you for joining us today. Our strong performance in 2015 reflected the benefit of our diversified business model and our focus on the real economy. Our contribution to the real economy in 2015 was broad-based and included originating $213 billion in residential mortgage loans, $31 billion of auto loans, almost $19 billion in new loan commitments to our small business customers, who primarily have less than $20 million in annual revenue, $34 billion of middle markets loans and $29 billion of Commercial Real Estate loans. We are active in facilitating the payments that drive economic activity across the country with over $280 billion of debit card purchase volume, $70 billion of consumer credit card purchase volume and $25 billion of commercial cards spend volume in 2015. We also contributed to the communities we serve in many other ways that are not directly reflected in our financial results, but are just as important to our success. For example, we've had the nations #1 United Way Campaign for 6 consecutive years.
Let me highlight a few of our other accomplishments during the past year. We generated earnings of $23 billion and earnings per share of $4.15. We grew revenue and pretax pre-provision profit. Our financial strength and competitive position have enabled us to capture opportunities for loan growth organically and through acquisitions, with average loans up $51 billion from a year ago, a 6% increase. Our deposit franchise once again generated strong customer and balanced growth, with average deposits up $80 billion or 7% from a year ago, and we grew the number of primary consumer checking customers by 5.6%. Our credit results continued to be very strong with our net charge-off rate declining to 33 basis points for the year. However, since we did not have any reserve release in the second half of the year, our provision expense increased $1 billion compared with a year ago. Our capital levels increased even as we returned more capital to shareholders. O,ur fifth consecutive year of increased returns. The returned $12.6 billion to our shareholders through common stock dividends and net share repurchases in 2015.
Turning to the economic environment. While parts of the global economy have continued to experience stress and the markets have reacted negatively in the early weeks of 2016, domestic economic conditions remain generally favorable. As you know, Wells Fargo is a U.S.-centric company and the strength and diversity of the U.S. economy benefited our results in 2015. The economy continues to advance, with strong job creation, including 70 consecutive months of gains in private payrolls, the longest run ever recorded. While falling energy prices have hurt certain sectors of the U.S. economy, most consumers and many businesses are benefiting from lower power cost, which results in more discretionary cash that can be used for other purposes. 
Auto vehicle sales were the best ever in 2015 and Wells Fargo originated a record number of auto loans during the year. If gas prices continue to remain low, 2016 should be another strong year for the auto market. The housing market also continued its steady improvement, with price appreciation of 6%, helping homeowners build equity and improving the credit quality of our consumer real estate portfolio, where net charge-offs were down 44% from a year ago. While December housing data is not yet available, 2015 appears to be the best year for home sales and housing starts since 2007. Inventories of homers for sale remain historically low, providing a tailwind for building activity into 2016. 
Commercial Real Estate appreciation has been even stronger than consumer real estate and vacancy rates, where nearly all property types continue to decline. For apartments, vacancy rates are at historic lows, which should benefit both construction activity and pricing in 2016. 
Finally, the building blocks of our long-term growth and increasing our customer base, deepening relationships and growing loans and deposits continue to be the foundation of our success. I'm excited about our opportunities to continue to build on these growth drivers in the year ahead as our team members remain focused on satisfying all of our customers' financial needs. 
John Shrewsberry, our Chief Financial Officer, will now provide more details on our results. John?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good morning, everyone. My comments will follow the presentation included in the quarterly supplement starting on Page 2. John and I will then answer your questions.We had another quarter of solid results. While our fourth quarter e
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good morning, everyone. My comments will follow the presentation included in the quarterly supplement starting on Page 2. John and I will then answer your questions.
We had another quarter of solid results. While our fourth quarter earnings were the same as the year ago, the fourth quarter of 2014 had the benefit of a credit reserve release and a gain from the sale of our government-guaranteed student loan portfolio. Our results this quarter demonstrated momentum across a variety of key business drivers. Compared with a year ago, we continue to have strong loan and deposit growth throughout our diversified commercial and consumer businesses. We grew revenue and pretax pre-provision profit, we had positive operating leverage as our expenses declined. Credit quality remained strong with net charge-offs of 36 basis points of average loans, and we continue to have strong liquidity and capital levels. 
Now let me highlight these key drivers in more detail.  On Page 3, we show the strong year-over-year growth John highlighted, including growing revenue, pretax pre-provision profit, loans, deposits and earnings per share. These results are even more impressive when you consider some of the headwinds we faced in 2015, while we continue to invest in our business. For example, loan-loss reserve releases declined from $1.6 billion in 2014 to $450 million in 2015. The sustained low rate environment and our disciplined redeployment of our strong deposit growth reduced our margin by 12 basis points. We continue to invest in risk management-related activities and these expenses were up 12% compared with 2014. We strengthened our balance sheet with increased liquidity and capital levels.
Turning to Page 4. We grew earning assets of 3% from third quarter with loans, short-term investments and investment securities all increasing. Our funding sources increased with continued deposit growth and increased long-term debt and short-term borrowings. Long-term debt increased $14.3 billion with $17.8 billion of issuances, including debt related to funding the previously announced GE Capital acquisitions. The debt we issued in the quarter had a weighted average maturity of about 8 years at a cost of approximately 3 months LIBOR plus 70 basis points. However, $10.5 billion of these issuances have a shorter maturity and become eligible for prepayment during the first half of '16. By beginning to prefund the GE Capital acquisitions, we are able to maintain our strong liquidity position and our healthy level of dry powder to fund perspective balance sheet growth, while retaining the flexibility to prepay a significant portion of the debt should we determine it is no longer needed.
Turning to the income statement overview on Page 5. Revenue declined to $289 million from the third quarter as growth in net interest income was offset by lower noninterest income, primarily due to the higher level of equity investment gains in the third quarter.
As shown on Page 6, we had continued strong broad-based loan growth in the fourth quarter. We've now achieved year-over-year loan growth for 18 consecutive quarters. Our core loan portfolio grew by $62.8 billion or a dollars [ph] or 8% from a year ago and was up $15.4 billion from the third quarter. Commercial loans grew $9.3 billion and consumer loans grew $6.1 billion from third quarter. We did not acquire any loan portfolios in the fourth quarter so the linked-quarter growth was all organic. The GE Capital transactions that we announced last quarter will start to be reflected in our first quarter results. The GE Railcar Services transaction, with  $4.1 billion of loans and leases closed on January 1, making us the largest rail car operating lessor in North America. We anticipate the North American base portion about 90% of the approximately $31 billion of assets we expect to acquire from GE Capital to close late in the first quarter, with the remainder expected to close in the second quarter. We're looking forward to having many talented and experienced people from these businesses join our team. Page 20 in the appendix has additional updates on these transactions.
On Page 7, we highlight the diversity of our loan growth. C&I loans were up $28.1 billion or 10% from a year ago. The growth was diversified across our wholesale businesses with double-digit growth in Commercial Real Estate, asset-backed finance, Corporate Banking, Equipment Finance, structured real estate and government and institutional banking. Core 1-4 Family First Mortgage loans grew $15.9 billion or 8% from a year ago and reflected continued growth and high-quality nonconforming mortgage loans. Commercial Real Estate loans grew $13.6 billion or 10% from a year ago and included the second quarter GE Capital acquisition and organic growth. Auto loans were up $4.2 billion or 8% from last year. We continue to benefit from the strong auto market, while we remained disciplined in our approach to credit and pricing. 
Other revolving credit and installment loans were up $3.3 billion or 9% from a year ago, with growth in securities-based lending, personal lines and loans and student loans. Credit card balances were up $2.9 billion or 9% from year ago, benefiting from new account growth and strong growth in active accounts as we experienced better activation rates on new accounts and more active users among our existing customers.
As highlighted on Page 8, we had $1.2 trillion of average deposits in the fourth quarter, up $67 billion or 6% from a year ago. Our average deposit cost was 8 basis points, down 1 basis point from a year ago and stable with third quarter. We stated that we believe deposit betas will be lower at least initially during this rate cycle and lower than they had been in past periods of rising rates. Indications since the rate move in December support this, however, we continue to monitor the market to ensure we remain competitive for our customers, while maintaining our disciplined relationship-based pricing strategy. This relationship focus has resulted in strong primary customer growth with primary consumer checking customers up 5.6% from a year ago and our primary small business and business banking checking customers up 4.8%.  Primary customers are over twice as profitable as non-primary customers.
Page 9 highlights Wells Fargo's revenue diversification and the balance between spread and fee income. Over the past year, as we've benefited from a balance sheet growth, we've been able to grow net interest income by 4%, while noninterest income has been relatively stable compared with the year ago. As a result, net interest income generated just over half of our revenue in the fourth quarter.
We grew net interest income $408 million from a year ago even as the net interest margin declined 12 basis points. The $131 million increase in net interest income from third quarter reflected growth in earning assets and higher income from variable sources, including periodic dividends, loan recoveries and fees. Net interest income also benefited modestly from the increase in interest rates late in the quarter. These benefits were partially offset by reduced income from seasonally lower balances of mortgages held for sale and increased interest expense from higher debt balances. The net interest margin declined 4 basis points from the third quarter. Income from variable sources improved the margin by 2 basis points, but was offset by a customer-driven deposit growth, which reduced the margin by 3 basis points that have a minimal impact on net interest income. All of the other repricing growth and mix reduced the margin by another 3 basis points, driven largely by increased debt balances, including the funding related to the GE Capital transactions that I mentioned earlier on the call. 
We demonstrated our ability to grow net interest income, which was up 4% from a year ago through balance sheet growth even in the challenging rate environment during 2015. On a full year basis, we believe we can increase net interest income in 2016 compared with 2015 in part due to the December rate increase and also from anticipated balance sheet growth. If there are additional rate increases during 2016, [ph] we would expect our net interest income growth for 2016 to be higher than the 4% growth rate we achieved in 2015.
Total noninterest income declined $420 million from third quarter, primarily driven by lower equity gains. Gains from equity investments were $423 million in the fourth quarter, which were in line with the quarterly average over the past 2 years. Equity gains declined 6% in the full year 2015 compared with 2014, and considering the current market conditions in our pipeline, we would expect continued declines in 2016. The volatile markets we've had so far this year could also impact our results and capital markets-related businesses, including Investment Banking and trading, and may also affect the asset-based valuations and transaction volumes in our market-driven businesses, including retail brokerage, asset management and trust. 
We had linked-quarter growth in a number of our businesses, including Investment Banking, card fees, Commercial Real Estate brokerage and Mortgage Banking. Mortgage Banking revenue increased $71 million from third quarter. Origination volume of $47 billion was down 15% from third quarter, reflecting the expected seasonal slowdown in the purchase market, but was up 7% from a year ago, benefiting from a stronger housing market. We ended the quarter with a $29 billion application pipeline, down 15% from third quarter, but up 12% from a year ago. Our production margin on residential, held-for-sale mortgage originations was 183 basis points in the fourth quarter, down from 188 basis points in the third quarter. Mortgage origination revenue in the fourth quarter benefited from $128 million repurchased reserve release as we resolved certain exposures and revised liability assumptions. Higher mortgage origination revenue also reflected stronger multifamily mortgage activity in the fourth quarter.
Other income declined $214 million from third quarter, driven by the impact of higher period and interest rates on our debt hedging results and the sale of warranty solutions last quarter, which benefited third quarter income. There are also a few linked quarter changes in some fee categories that were not driven by business activity. Merchant processing fees as reported declined $182 million linked quarter. These fees are now reported in other income as results of accounting change, which was P&L neutral. The increasing gains from trading activities this quarter was due to higher deferred compensation gains, which are offset in employee benefits, and they are also P&L neutral.
As shown on Page 12, expenses were stable with the third quarter and we remain focused on expense management. There are a few items to highlight that impacted the linked-quarter trend in some specific categories. The increase in employee benefits expense reflected $319 million of higher deferred comp expense, which was primarily offset in trading revenue. Operating losses were down $191 million from third quarter from the lower litigation accruals, while foreclosed asset expense declined $89 million due to Commercial Real Estate recoveries. Also, third quarter expenses included $126 million  contribution to the Wells Fargo Foundation. A number of our expenses are typically higher in the fourth quarter. Equipment expense was up $181 million, primarily due to annual software license renewals outside professional services increased $164 million, which included higher project-related spending. Advertising expenses were also elevated, up $49 million. While these typically higher fourth quarter expense should be lower next quarter, as usual, we will have seasonally higher personnel expenses in the first quarter, reflecting incentive compensation and employee benefits expense. 
Our efficiency ratio was 57.8% for the full year 2015, and we currently expect to operate at the higher end of our efficiency ratio range of 55% to 59% for the full year 2016.
Turning to our business segments starting on Page 13. Community Banking earned $3.3 billion in the fourth quarter, down 1% from a year ago and down 7% from third quarter. We continue to grow the number of retail bank households we serve and we're focused on building lifelong relationships with our customers by providing them exceptional customer service. In fact, we were ranked #1 in customer satisfaction in the National Bank category according to the 2015 American Customer Satisfaction Index. We are growing our credit and debit card businesses through new customer growth and increased usage among existing customers. Debit card purchase volume was $73 billion in the fourth quarter, up 8% from a year ago; and credit card purchase volume was $18.9 billion, up 12% from a year ago. Our credit card penetration in Retail Banking households increased to 43.4% in the fourth quarter, up from 41.5% a year ago. We received the highest-ranking and corporate insight assessment of credit card issuer rewards redemption options, and just this week, we launch of the new American Express card with no annual fee. Our customers are also increasingly using our digital offerings with active online customers up 7% and active mobile customers up 14% from a year ago. To better support our customers to grow their companies, we've moved business banking and merchant payment services, which were previously included within Community Banking, to Wholesale Banking. For comparative purposes, prior period segment results have been revised to reflect this realignment.
Wholesale Banking earned $2.1 billion in the fourth quarter, stable from year ago and up 9% from third quarter. The linked quarter both reflected higher net interest and noninterest income. The increase in fee income driven by Investment Banking and gains from the sale of equity fund investments driven by Volker as well as Commercial Real Estate-related businesses such as, E-still Secured our Commercial Real Estate brokerage and advisory business, multifamily capital and structured real estate. Revenue also benefited from continued balance sheet growth with average loans up 13% from a year ago, the fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit year-over-year growth. Average deposits grew 6% from a year ago. We remain disciplined in our deposit pricing for our wholesale customers and we were focused on relationship-based pricing for both deposits and loans.
Wealth and Investment Management earned $595 million in the fourth quarter, up 15% from a year ago and down 2% from third quarter. Growth from a year ago is driven by positive operating leverage with expenses down 2% and revenue up 1%. Revenue reflected strong balance sheet growth with net interest income up 15% from a year ago. Average deposits grew 7% [ph] from a year ago and average loans grew 15%, the 10th consecutive quarter of double-digit year-over-year loan growth. Loan growth was broad-based with strong client demand across a number of product offerings, including high-quality, nonconforming mortgage loans, commercial loans and security-based lending. Retail brokerage managed account assets were up 3% from third quarter and down 1% from a year ago. The decline from a year ago reflected lower market valuations, which were partially offset by positive flows.
Turning to Page 16. Credit quality remained strong, demonstrated the benefit of our diversified portfolio. Our net charge-off rate was 36 basis points of average loans. Net charge-offs increased $128 million from third quarter, reflecting $90 million of higher losses in our oil and gas portfolio, which totaled $118 million in the fourth quarter, an seasonally higher consumer losses. The performance of our consumer real estate portfolios, which are at 36% of our loans outstanding, continue to benefit from the improving housing market. 
Nonperforming assets have declined for 13 consecutive quarters and were down $497 million from third quarter, driven by improvements in our commercial and consumer real estate portfolios and the $342 million reduction in foreclosed assets. Oil and gas loan accruals were $843 million, up $277 million from third quarter. However, as of year-end, over 90% of our nonaccrual  oil and gas loans were current on interest payments. We didn't have a reserve release or build in the fourth quarter as the improvement in our residential real estate portfolios was offset by higher commercial reserves, reflecting the impact from our oil and gas portfolio. Total loans in our oil and gas portfolio were down 6% from a year ago and are now less than 2% of total loans outstanding. We continue to work closely with our customers and are mondering market conditions, and we have reset borrowing base determinations twice since energy prices started to decline in late 2014. However, as we've mentioned in the past, it takes time for losses to emerge, and at current price levels, we would expect another higher oil and gas losses in 2016. We've considered the challenges within the energy sector and our allowance process throughout 2015 and approximately $1.2 billion of the allowance was allocated to our oil and gas portfolio. It's important to note that the entire allowances available to absorb credit losses inherent in the total loan portfolio. We've also considered the impact of lower energy prices on our debt and equity securities portfolio and had approximately $130 million of OTTI-related write-downs in our energy-related holdings in the quarter.
Turning to Page 17. Our capital levels remained strong with our estimated common equity Tier 1 ratio, fully phased-in at 10.7% in the fourth quarter, well above the regulatory minimum and buffers in our internal -- and buffers -- regulatory minimum and buffers and our internal buffer. Our strong capital generation positioned us well for the acquisitions we announced in 2015 and returning more capital to shareholders. We returned $3.2 billion or shareholders in the fourth quarter through common stock dividends and net share repurchases and our net payout ratio is 59%.
In summary, our fourth quarter and full year results demonstrated the benefit of our diversified business model with strong growth in loans and deposits and consistent earnings. We continued to invest in our businesses, grew capital and liquidity and maintained a strong risk culture. We are excited about the opportunities ahead and expect our customer base to grow both organically and through acquisitions, including from the customers and platforms we are acquiring from GE Capital in 2016. We remain focused on satisfying our new and existing customers' financial needs. 
John and I will now answer your questions.

componenttext: Of the -- well, we're focused on the whole thing. Half of those customers, half of those balances represent ENP companies upstream companies. 1/4 of them represent oilfield services companies and 1/4 of them represent pipelines and storage and other midstream activity. And it excludes what I would describe as investment grade diversified larger cap companies where we don't view the credit exposure as quite the same. And not much of that to begin with.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just more broadly speaking mean, obviously, it's a very balanced loan portfolio and there's [indiscernible] consumer heavy or anything. But any thoughts on how much more improvement there's still to come on the consumer side, assuming maybe
componenttext: Okay. And then just more broadly speaking mean, obviously, it's a very balanced loan portfolio and there's [indiscernible] consumer heavy or anything. But any thoughts on how much more improvement there's still to come on the consumer side, assuming maybe the macro either holds or just has a stop patch overall as there's still some embedded improvement that we could see, I guess, in the real estate portfolio on the consumer side?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, our outlook for housing in 2016 is actually pretty strong. We've got a little bit more supply coming in. We've got more household formation. You've got -- we're going to have a 4 [ph] handle on unemployment before you know it, and we've got
componenttext: Well, I mean, our outlook for housing in 2016 is actually pretty strong. We've got a little bit more supply coming in. We've got more household formation. You've got -- we're going to have a 4 [ph] handle on unemployment before you know it, and we've got lower rates. So that continues to be true, that's probably a continued tailwind in terms of some of the drivers of the estimation of embedded loss on the consumer real estate side of the loan portfolio. And we're not putting a number on it because we only know when we get there. I think that's supportive.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on energy question. You indicated during the prepared remarks that over 90% of the portfolio's current and that you've reset 2 times. But if prices stay where they are today, you'd have higher losses in '16. I just wanted to understand, m
componenttext: Just a follow-up on energy question. You indicated during the prepared remarks that over 90% of the portfolio's current and that you've reset 2 times. But if prices stay where they are today, you'd have higher losses in '16. I just wanted to understand, maybe give us a sense of, as oil price comes down here, what kind of rate of change we should be expecting as we're building out the model in '16 for provisions?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I make 1 correction to your setup there, which is over 90% of nonperforming oil and gas loans are performing. All of the other ones are performing. In terms of rate of change, when we think about the allowance that we have today, frankly, we could ima
componenttext: Can I make 1 correction to your setup there, which is over 90% of nonperforming oil and gas loans are performing. All of the other ones are performing. In terms of rate of change, when we think about the allowance that we have today, frankly, we could imagine prices not improving from where they are today. And so the rate of change of how loans actually move to loss reflects a lot of things, and that's not just price. It reflects the [indiscernible] which we just described for Matt, the distribution of upstream midstream services in each of them behaved differently. We've got customers that are oil or gas heavy depending on what their business model looks a little bit different basin by basin around the country and by method of extraction as well. So there's a lot more to what losses are going to look like in '16 than just the spot price or the expected near forward price of crude. Having said that, we've sensitized, such that we are sitting here at the $30 area a year from now and believe that our allowance accurately or appropriately reflects the lost content that we may have.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: And Betsy, just to add. We have some of the most skilled people, 250 or so folks would then, in this industry a long time, have seen changes and we're focused on this. But as Matt just asked a few minutes ago, we also should step back and look at the entire portfolio. When you have 36% of your loans, as John mentioned, in [indiscernible] real estate, small improvement there is huge for this company. All portfolios are important, but I just want to make sure we look at this in perspective.

And when you add it up it's -- it would appear to be a little bit heavier than some of the others who have reported.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore ISI.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the energy side again, just -- do you have the criticized energy ratio for that portfolio? And then separately, just get into that sensitivity question. If we did see oil fall into the 20s and stay there, $20 to $25 range, can you give us just some ide
componenttext: On the energy side again, just -- do you have the criticized energy ratio for that portfolio? And then separately, just get into that sensitivity question. If we did see oil fall into the 20s and stay there, $20 to $25 range, can you give us just some idea of how the magnitude of the increase and the loss migration under that scenario?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So criticized assets to date or at the end of the quarter in that portfolio are about 38% of outstandings. And it's -- there isn't a simple way to dimension what the change would be in losses based on some other future price income. As I mentioned t
componenttext: Sure. So criticized assets to date or at the end of the quarter in that portfolio are about 38% of outstandings. And it's -- there isn't a simple way to dimension what the change would be in losses based on some other future price income. As I mentioned to Betsy, we're sensitizing our portfolio based on a continuation of very, very, very low oil prices than the context where we are today rather than an upward sloping curve in addition to scenarios that included upward sloping curve, and we are comfortable with the amount of coverage that we have today. That's how I think about it.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then separately, on the spread revenue side, you indicated that net interest income should grow -- it could exceed the 4% growth that you saw in '15 if you get hiked. How many hikes are you assuming? And how much greater than the 4% w
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then separately, on the spread revenue side, you indicated that net interest income should grow -- it could exceed the 4% growth that you saw in '15 if you get hiked. How many hikes are you assuming? And how much greater than the 4% will it be?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've got a 1 hike, 2 hike, 3 hike and 4-hike scenario that we're operating list because like you, we can't say for sure what's going to happen. We've done it -- we've worked very hard to produce the type of net interest income growth that we have
componenttext: Yes, so we've got a 1 hike, 2 hike, 3 hike and 4-hike scenario that we're operating list because like you, we can't say for sure what's going to happen. We've done it -- we've worked very hard to produce the type of net interest income growth that we have in the no-hike environment for the last several years. So we'll see what the future holds, because it feels a little bit different every day. But if we got 3 or 4 hikes, could we end up in mid- to high single-digit percentage growth rates for net interest income? That math would pencil out. It's going to be a function of organic loan growth, closing on our GE portfolios that we've been talking about and then the number of hikes to come and when they come.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then lastly, what would that mean in terms of the margin outlook if you to get under those hike scenarios?
componenttext: Okay. Then lastly, what would that mean in terms of the margin outlook if you to get under those hike scenarios?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it begins to expand. It's ---- another way of thinking about it is we would've expect it to begin to expand until continued hikes begin to layer in, particularly as we said, while we've prefunded a little bit of debt so that we're in a great positio
componenttext: Well, it begins to expand. It's ---- another way of thinking about it is we would've expect it to begin to expand until continued hikes begin to layer in, particularly as we said, while we've prefunded a little bit of debt so that we're in a great position to close on these assets that we're acquiring. So that's a little bit of a margin headwind. That has to -- those loans have to hit the books so that, that burns off, and then we need to have -- took that first 25 basis points move, while important and symbolic, doesn't really do much, even though we've been very slow to react or appropriately slow to react in terms of our own deposit pricing activity. There's Subsequent one that would have a meaningful impact on margin. Having said all that, what we're really focused on is going dollars of net interest income. And the balance sheet structural issues, as we have rapid deposit growth or funding activity, et cetera, that have an impact on the margin, but it's about dollars for us.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Erika Najarian of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Erika Najarian of Bank of America.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the efficiency guide for full year 2016 at the upper end of your 55% to 59% range, you noted that for the full year 2015, you're at 57.8%. And I'm wondering if you could walk us through the puts and takes in terms of operating leverage staying flat? An
componenttext: On the efficiency guide for full year 2016 at the upper end of your 55% to 59% range, you noted that for the full year 2015, you're at 57.8%. And I'm wondering if you could walk us through the puts and takes in terms of operating leverage staying flat? And also to follow up John's question, how many interest rate hikes is that upper end of the 55% to 59% range on efficiency embedded?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of puts and takes in '15 versus '16, we're still in an elevated time for what I would describe as compliance risk management technology, including cyber-related spend. We're still in an elevated time of product development and sort of offensiv
componenttext: So in terms of puts and takes in '15 versus '16, we're still in an elevated time for what I would describe as compliance risk management technology, including cyber-related spend. We're still in an elevated time of product development and sort of offensive-related spend. And so I think that, that's part of what guides us to this higher end for the time being. One notable difference in '16 versus '15, I'm not sure if anybody else is focused on this in their calls, but we also have this new incremental FDIC insurance surcharge every bank over $10 billion in assets. And that's worth $480 million pretax to Wells Fargo for its partial year impact in 2016, so we're all going to have something like that for the next year or 2 while that works its way through. So I would think about that and that begins, I think, in Q2 of '16. And then if it's enacted in its current form, which it's anticipated to be. So if we have 2 or 3 moves in 2016 by the Fed and if they happen ratably throughout the course of the year, that incremental revenue will have a beneficial impact on efficiency ratio, but I don't know that it drives us below the middle of the range. So I think the range is still appropriate.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll probably focus more on that in the other targets that we give in our May Investor Day. There's a little bit of time between now and then to release at the course for the next couple of years that reflects the environment that reflect the balance she
componenttext: We'll probably focus more on that in the other targets that we give in our May Investor Day. There's a little bit of time between now and then to release at the course for the next couple of years that reflects the environment that reflect the balance sheet structure that we have that reflect our expense profile. But I still feel like it's appropriate to think about the higher end of the range, so the 57% to 59% for this year. Unless rates really, really begin to move, which seems hard to imagine, sitting here at this moment.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Erica, how we think about expenses around here is that we are pretty tightfisted when it comes to making sure that the expenses -- the investments we do make have shareholder benefits to them. As John mentioned, defensive, offensive, we're spending a
componenttext: And Erica, how we think about expenses around here is that we are pretty tightfisted when it comes to making sure that the expenses -- the investments we do make have shareholder benefits to them. As John mentioned, defensive, offensive, we're spending a lot of money in compliance and cyber. On the other hand, we're also spending a lot of money on items and issues and things that create convenience for customers, mobile payments and a whole bunch of other things. And we always try to take a long-term view, but there's a lot of discussion that takes place about managing expenses and making sure the investments we're making do have a long-term payoff for us.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just I heard you loud and clear in terms of the proportion of your energy exposure relative to the consumer side. But my question on this is really on CCAR. I'm wondering, did you get enough color back from your regulators in terms of how oil a
componenttext: Great. And just I heard you loud and clear in terms of the proportion of your energy exposure relative to the consumer side. But my question on this is really on CCAR. I'm wondering, did you get enough color back from your regulators in terms of how oil and gas losses were stressed in the 2015 CCAR? And how that level is comparing to the base case right now that's embedded in your reserve? I think the next question for investors is a worry that while everybody seems appropriately -- could be appropriately reserved for actual, that there could be an exorbitant amount of stress applied to the portfolio in 2016 CCAR?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's certainly possible. We haven't gotten those instructions for that specific scenario analysis yet. Separately, what surprised you that we are very transparent, we spend a lot of time talking with the regulatory community about what's going on in energ
componenttext: It's certainly possible. We haven't gotten those instructions for that specific scenario analysis yet. Separately, what surprised you that we are very transparent, we spend a lot of time talking with the regulatory community about what's going on in energy and they are fully aware of how our portfolio works. But as you mentioned at the beginning of that statement, it's important to remember that we're talking about 2% of the $920 billion loan portfolio. So they know that, we know that and the math benefits from that.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Carcache with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Carcache with Nomura Securities.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does good decision by one of our large competitors to pass the 25 basis points increase through to their commercial depositors influence at all the -- how you guys viewed the degree to which you and others in the industry will benefit from higher rates?
componenttext: Does good decision by one of our large competitors to pass the 25 basis points increase through to their commercial depositors influence at all the -- how you guys viewed the degree to which you and others in the industry will benefit from higher rates?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it depends. I mean, our wholesale teams and  there are -- each of the different customer segment relationship teams provides a different set of insight under what to compare their competitive set is doing. There are some banks who, I think, are, sounds
componenttext: So it depends. I mean, our wholesale teams and  there are -- each of the different customer segment relationship teams provides a different set of insight under what to compare their competitive set is doing. There are some banks who, I think, are, sounds like, anyway, are being a little quicker to raise deposit rates. And in the wholesale space, they were on -- we're competing on service, we're completing on product, we're competing on a lot of things. And margin, there's also the impact of price for certain balances. Some of that -- some deposits are worth more than others from a liquidity point of view. Some relationships are worth more than others, and I'd say we're very in tune with what we think we need to do to maintain relationships and to reward customers, where we have a big relationship and a lot going on. So we've been through this before, and we tried to stay really focused though on customer and providing them great value. And I think what John is saying, what we're all saying is there's value to the entire relationship. There is value to the progress we have in services, and surely, deposit pricing is one of those value items, but it's not a standalone item.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one observation I would add, this is very early days in this is that some of the feedback I've seen, the customers who seem to be the most price sensitive on the deposits are the customers whose deposits have the lowest liquidity value to Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And one observation I would add, this is very early days in this is that some of the feedback I've seen, the customers who seem to be the most price sensitive on the deposits are the customers whose deposits have the lowest liquidity value to Wells Fargo. So sometimes it's easy to see those go.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Separately, if I may. I saw your recent transaction update on Slide 20, but was hoping you could give a little more color on client retention initiatives and whether there any issues there? And some of those acquired specialty finance businesses l
componenttext: Got it. Separately, if I may. I saw your recent transaction update on Slide 20, but was hoping you could give a little more color on client retention initiatives and whether there any issues there? And some of those acquired specialty finance businesses like Vendor Finance, for example, are nitchy. And it feels like Wells and GE and the CITs of the world really played in those areas. So just curious whether GE's exit, you think, increases your ability to grow share across those businesses as we look forward from here?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly hope that it does. And I'd say in Vendor in particular, I think we mentioned this when we announced the deal. But as you described, GE has great business that's close to the OEM that helps them finance their sales through their customers. Fro
componenttext: We certainly hope that it does. And I'd say in Vendor in particular, I think we mentioned this when we announced the deal. But as you described, GE has great business that's close to the OEM that helps them finance their sales through their customers. From a Wells Fargo perspective, most of those OEMs are already customers to Wells Fargo in one way or another. And most of their customers are already -- or many of their customers are already customers of Wells Fargo one way or another, so it's a way for us to really enrich the relationship, get closer to the manufacturer and in some cases, expand the program that we may already have been a smaller player in. And in other -- many other cases to create a program or to step into a program is working well. But I'd say overall, the customer reception has been great. And as our leaders have reached out and traveled around with our new GE teammates and talked to the customers of GE businesses. So I think there's -- I don't think customer retention has not surfaced as an issue. It's just a question of how quickly and how well we can expand the product penetration, given all that Wells Fargo has to offer the wholesale customer in each of those instances.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on fees. Specifically, if we start on the brokerage business obviously, the market values are now weighing on the underlying growth, but I was wondering if you could just give us your outlook for growth in the brokerage business, which unfo
componenttext: My question is on fees. Specifically, if we start on the brokerage business obviously, the market values are now weighing on the underlying growth, but I was wondering if you could just give us your outlook for growth in the brokerage business, which unfortunately has comped now a little negative on a year-over-year basis. But can you just kind of distinguish between market levels impacts and what you're seeing from a customer activity perspective as we look to '16?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I mean, it's made a little bit more complicated by what's going on in these couple of weeks in terms of just with respect to the impact of asset-based fund or fee type arrangements, so it's hard to ballpark at the moment. But we have good, strong gr
componenttext: Sure, I mean, it's made a little bit more complicated by what's going on in these couple of weeks in terms of just with respect to the impact of asset-based fund or fee type arrangements, so it's hard to ballpark at the moment. But we have good, strong growth of inflows in both accounts and account assets. And if we were to more normalized S&P environment then we'd be talking about the continuity of single-digit percentage growth working for us for the last few years. But when you overlay this market and instability, it depends, a, on what levels we end up, because that will influence what we're multiplying times a few schedule; and b, what customers do, whether customers stay invested, get more invested or back away as volatility increases. I think, it's expectation to continue to grow the business by adding new customers, to encourage customers to stay invested if that's appropriate for where they are in their investing life cycle to use these as entry points for people who have more money to put to work and longer-term goals. So it's going come and go, move a little bit as equity markets move up and down. But I think what we're talking about in revenue terms, even with the type of pullback that we've had in the first quarter hundreds of millions of dollars worth of net income sensitivity if we weren't to recover from here and if we didn't have a meaningful new client growth over the course of the year.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just on the mortgage business. If you could also just ex the MSR drive, which can swing big up or down, how much more retention do we still have over the servicing portfolio? And what's your expectation if it's different than just kind
componenttext: And then secondly, just on the mortgage business. If you could also just ex the MSR drive, which can swing big up or down, how much more retention do we still have over the servicing portfolio? And what's your expectation if it's different than just kind of MBA, and if ready for the -- what you think the mortgage market does in the year ahead?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think the MBA is calling for $1.5 trillion or $1.6 trillion, now the $1.4 trillion mortgage market in '16 versus '15 and our folks seem to be in sync with that. In terms of servicing, retrenching, it's -- we'll get to a more normalized level of
componenttext: Yes, so I think the MBA is calling for $1.5 trillion or $1.6 trillion, now the $1.4 trillion mortgage market in '16 versus '15 and our folks seem to be in sync with that. In terms of servicing, retrenching, it's -- we'll get to a more normalized level of defaulted loan workout activity over the course of the next couple of years as that -- the full crisis era inventory works its way off, and then we'll find out what the stabilized run rate is for productivity for how many people it takes to service that portfolio of our size that's behaving more normally. And so there is incremental benefit to take out, but we're not in a hurry to do it. It's more important that the loans are serviced properly and the customers are dealt with in the way that they require. But, so there's some upside there. And unreimbursed servicing cost, I'd say are -- as we look out, they start to improve quarter by quarter over the course of the next several, so that's 1 benefit that we'll see. But in terms of the market overall, we're still -- we're very, very big in conforming with Fannie and Freddie and there's more to do there. We think of it as more of a purchase market as we go forward, specially if rates increase, although they're going the other way right now. And as I mentioned a little bit earlier, some of the early indicators for purchase activity look really good. More jobs, more available housing to buy and more people moving into prime first-time homebuyer and second-time home buyer age cohorts. Those are all very supportive. So --

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And household formation.
componenttext: And household formation.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Household formation is up meaningfully.
componenttext: Household formation is up meaningfully.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Meaningfully.
componenttext: Meaningfully.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that's good news.
componenttext: So that's good news.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, at this point, most of my questions have been answered, but maybe on the energy portfolio just broadly. If you guys can speak to how -- just how you're treating customers at a top level? And if you think there's a sense that banks are not necessa
componenttext: I think, at this point, most of my questions have been answered, but maybe on the energy portfolio just broadly. If you guys can speak to how -- just how you're treating customers at a top level? And if you think there's a sense that banks are not necessarily pulling back credit the way you might -- you have this kind of correction in any other sort of asset value, such as just at the top-level. And then, John, I think you had said in your comments about the NPAs there, I just want to make sure I heard that correctly. Is at 90% of the oil and gas NPAs are current interest only? I just want to make sure that I heard that correctly as well.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Current on interest is what I said.
componenttext: Current on interest is what I said.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of pullback in credit availability, I would expand the description to say not just bank credit, but capital markets are actually, as you know, sort of quite open for energy companies. very early and this and that has gone away. My understandin
componenttext: So in terms of pullback in credit availability, I would expand the description to say not just bank credit, but capital markets are actually, as you know, sort of quite open for energy companies. very early and this and that has gone away. My understanding is that the smaller banks, regional banks have only recently begun to really pullback from the willingness to provide credit and maybe it's this incremental leg down to where we are in crude prices that has people generally believing that this could be where we are for a longer time. I wouldn't say that there's a tremendous demand for incremental credit right now. It's more about how quickly you're asking or require your customers to come into conformance under their borrowing base. What you're doing with their excess cash, what they're doing with that CapEx program. And I'd say we're all being as appropriately tough to make sure that we protect the interest of the bank. We are very -- we're ready with these customers to help them work through this doesn't do us any good to accelerate an issue or 2 to end up as the holder of a number of oil leases as a bank. And so there's -- that dictates some of the cadence. Services companies, I think, our different than ENP companies, because for some of them are really not about $5 bend of oil prices or a $10 bend of oil prices. They're either in business or they're not in business. And if they're not in business, you got to figure out how to maximize the recovery as quickly as possible, because some of their inventory, which is security for the loan, maybe very single purpose, and that's a little bit of a different workout. I don't know if that's helpful, but that's how we are seeing it.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color.
componenttext: I appreciate the color.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the mortgage banking side, can you talk a little bit about how trade has impacted the mortgage bank on the mortgage banking revenues? It looks like you guys did a pretty good quarter despite a lot of disruptions that trick brought to the market.
componenttext: On the mortgage banking side, can you talk a little bit about how trade has impacted the mortgage bank on the mortgage banking revenues? It looks like you guys did a pretty good quarter despite a lot of disruptions that trick brought to the market.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we spent a lot of time preparing ourselves for a technology-wise, data management-wise so that we could flip the switch and collect data and have the right disclosures, et cetera. We've not seen a meaningful impact to our results in our retail cha
componenttext: Yes. So we spent a lot of time preparing ourselves for a technology-wise, data management-wise so that we could flip the switch and collect data and have the right disclosures, et cetera. We've not seen a meaningful impact to our results in our retail channel are from our work with correspondence. There are probably some lower volume programs that we or others would have deemphasized, preparing ourselves for the new requirements in our bigger programs. So as those have come online, et cetera maybe we see a little bit of a snapback, but you wouldn't even notice that in the numbers. So for the most part, the impact I'd say has been immaterial.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: And then in the -- in 2015, specially in the second half of the year, we saw on the macro data, and I think your micro data, a big tickup purchase originations, probably third quarter is the largest origination quarter for purchases since '07, '08. Do you think trade interrupted that? Are you still seeing very strong demand for the purchase market despite all this volatility?

componenttext: Okay. And expectations for earnings accretion turned a little bit more positive in your update. Anything changed there or you just refined investment from when you first did the deal?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the latter. It's Refining the estimate of the expenses that we're going to consume to properly transition all the team members to do data workaround customers, et cetera, although just it's important to say a big emphasis here is on the lifetime rela
componenttext: It's the latter. It's Refining the estimate of the expenses that we're going to consume to properly transition all the team members to do data workaround customers, et cetera, although just it's important to say a big emphasis here is on the lifetime relationship we're going to have with these customers. I know it's important to you guys to get what the first few months mean, but we are much more concerned on an orderly transition and a nice integration and a good feeling for both customers and team members, and that's expensive.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on TLAC, any update on potential TLAC issuance? I think your original estimate was $40 billion to $60 billion. And have you done some the already? And what would be maybe the timing or timeframe over which you did the rest?
componenttext: Okay. And then on TLAC, any update on potential TLAC issuance? I think your original estimate was $40 billion to $60 billion. And have you done some the already? And what would be maybe the timing or timeframe over which you did the rest?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the estimate's still the same. We did do a little bit in the fourth quarter, $6 billion to $7 billion, I think, in the fourth quarter of what would be TLAC eligible. This is a little bit of a subtlety. But now that the NPR is out, and while the NPR is
componenttext: So the estimate's still the same. We did do a little bit in the fourth quarter, $6 billion to $7 billion, I think, in the fourth quarter of what would be TLAC eligible. This is a little bit of a subtlety. But now that the NPR is out, and while the NPR is out, there's a little ambiguity about what's eligible and what's not. And so that will slow down issuance during the NPR period so that none of us issue something that turns out not to be either conforming or grandfathered. So it'll be slow year for a quarter or 2 probably. But it's our goal to get our full requirement, whatever it ultimately is, in place with plenty of room before the actual -- the final phase in date of 1 1 22. So we'll update folks as we go along. We still have to know where we are in that journey and what the impact is.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: John, you talked about the economy, but what's customer sentiment like lately? Are you seeing much confidence to borrow and make investments? And given the macro uncertainties and also customers benefiting from lower gas prices, are you seeing much willingness to spend?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So far, Joe, with this particular consumers, there've not spent a lot of their gas savings so far. I think you'll start to sense more -- and the thing for Wells Fargo is 97% of what we do is in the U.S. and virtually everything we do in the U.S. is involv
componenttext: So far, Joe, with this particular consumers, there've not spent a lot of their gas savings so far. I think you'll start to sense more -- and the thing for Wells Fargo is 97% of what we do is in the U.S. and virtually everything we do in the U.S. is involved in real economy. And there are pockets of strength. You think of autos, you think of Commercial Real Estate, you think of [indiscernible] and real estate, parts of ag, middle-market, and I'm not going to say its robust, but we are really happy were all in the U.S. let's put it that way.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then how did  also, how did the recruitment of the Credit Suisse private bankers go relative to expectations? And was there any impact from this on expenses this quarter? And what would be the magnitude and timing of the assets under management you mi
componenttext: And then how did  also, how did the recruitment of the Credit Suisse private bankers go relative to expectations? And was there any impact from this on expenses this quarter? And what would be the magnitude and timing of the assets under management you might expect to transfer over>

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's going along, as David would describe it, as planned in terms of the number of people who have or will be joining Wells Fargo. And we think they've actually disclosed a number on that, but it's a good outcome. And I assume it'll take 1 to 2
componenttext: So I think it's going along, as David would describe it, as planned in terms of the number of people who have or will be joining Wells Fargo. And we think they've actually disclosed a number on that, but it's a good outcome. And I assume it'll take 1 to 2 quarters after people join for them to begin to migrate their customer accounts over to Wells Fargo. That's probably more of a second half impact. And frankly, with -- even with the maximum number of people, the total people that we originally referred to in that arrangement that we have with Credit Suisse, what it looks like is 3, 4 or 5 months worth of organic financial adviser equipment. It's not a huge game changer in terms of the numbers. It's great, we got the exact right people for our platform, they have a lot of capability, they have a lot of great customer relationships that we are excited to have. But I would think of that more as a modest acceleration of what would have been organic activity rather than a gamechanging activity in the segment.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous Research.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, there is an industrial company reporting as you're speaking, so I don't mean to hijack his [indiscernible] we haven't heard of it. And I don't know if I'm pronouncing it right, Fastenol or something. But they're kind of making the statement th
componenttext: So I guess, there is an industrial company reporting as you're speaking, so I don't mean to hijack his [indiscernible] we haven't heard of it. And I don't know if I'm pronouncing it right, Fastenol or something. But they're kind of making the statement that in an industrial recession, they're seeing some of the underlying customers with the orders down 25%-plus year-over-year. So I'm wondering if you could comment, like when you just talk to that kind of industrial component of your customer base, who maybe is more exposed to cutbacks by the energy industry and the strong dollar, do you think it's possible we actually are in an industrial recession right now?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my observation would be for certainly for folks who are selling into the energy extraction or processing businesses, it's been a tough year, and we continue to being surprised that those orders were only down 25%. But I think more broadly at least as i
componenttext: So my observation would be for certainly for folks who are selling into the energy extraction or processing businesses, it's been a tough year, and we continue to being surprised that those orders were only down 25%. But I think more broadly at least as it reveals itself in our own customer activity, people who are more reliant on exports have been -- were early and hit hard by how strong the dollar has become over the course of the last couple of years. And -- but more broadly, as John described, it's not robust, people aren't super enthusiastic. But you've seen the growth in our commercial loan portfolios, which reflects people doing business. And a lot of that is us taking business from other people, but  in a significant portion of those cases, that's folks borrowing money to do things, to buy things. And it doesn't feel like a manufacturing recession to me, although I'm sensitive to manufacturers who ship everything overseas and who are trying to sell it in dollars, because that's a more expensive proposition.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you also, as John mentioned, we're a very diversified company. We went to all sectors in the economy. Farmers, ranchers. 2% of our loan is oil and gas, commercial real estate, middle-market. So you're going to have some companies, because of what
componenttext: Yes. And you also, as John mentioned, we're a very diversified company. We went to all sectors in the economy. Farmers, ranchers. 2% of our loan is oil and gas, commercial real estate, middle-market. So you're going to have some companies, because of what they're doing, are going to be impacted more than others. And I can see where Fastenol, it's a Midwestern company. I know the company it's a great company. We'll have some issues or we'll be saying things that makes sense to me, given their product mix.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought they were based in Minnesota? So I figured it was fair to ask.
componenttext: I thought they were based in Minnesota? So I figured it was fair to ask.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that, they're great.
componenttext: I know that, they're great.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, stepping back on fees. I guess, one of the things that strikes me looking at the model is the kind of bouncing around $10 million a quarter ever since the Wachovia deal, and I guess that speaks to some of the benefit diversity of the business
componenttext: And I guess, stepping back on fees. I guess, one of the things that strikes me looking at the model is the kind of bouncing around $10 million a quarter ever since the Wachovia deal, and I guess that speaks to some of the benefit diversity of the business, because there have been some headwinds like the mortgage bubble popping and all that. Do you think we are finally at the point, where the underlying business momentum that you clearly generated can start leading to higher reported consolidated fees? Or is there still maybe another year of headwinds with the lower equity markets and lower refi volumes and stuff like that?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the bigger categories would be deposit service charges to both consumer and commercial, and I'd say there's a nice trajectory there. And we've suffered -- well, not suffered. We were impacted in a way, call it an immediate post-merger time frame where
componenttext: So the bigger categories would be deposit service charges to both consumer and commercial, and I'd say there's a nice trajectory there. And we've suffered -- well, not suffered. We were impacted in a way, call it an immediate post-merger time frame where things were cut back and growing, and they been growing nicely and continue to adding new customers and adding new capability. So that's a strength and something that will continue to grow. Card fees with big emphasis there, both debit and credit, are moving down the path to really grow our credit card business. I think we'll help there in the Wealth and Investment Management business since we talked about the portion of it will be a function of what happens with equity markets. But we're growing the customer base, we're growing assets under management and we're -- and that may be more volatile, given what's going on with the S&P. But certainly, a series of growth over any reasonable time frame. Those categories are bread-and-butter fundamental banking activity that we feel really good about. At the margin, we still -- we also have as, we mentioned, stepped down to a more normalized level of equity gains. That's something that has to be grown through. In your analysis, the mortgage market as we said, even if we are doing more, if that market isn't growing much of that, then we'll be impacted one way or the other by that. So it's our goal to work to grow the aggregation of those line items in the way that you're describing. But each of them has their own character, but diversification has worked for us over the past several years as you mentioned. But there's a lot to do to grow them.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And now let's just pull the ones back  a little bit. John you've been through many cycles and I'm just wondering, is the decline in the oil and gas sector similar to other industry-specific declines that then spillover in the broader economy?  In ot
componenttext: Okay. And now let's just pull the ones back  a little bit. John you've been through many cycles and I'm just wondering, is the decline in the oil and gas sector similar to other industry-specific declines that then spillover in the broader economy?  In other words, what comes to my mind is 2002 TMT Marriott Enron, road, you had a spillover effect, you had some market concerns you have some losses. What other period does this seems similar to? Or is this stretching too much? The oil and gas is fine, it's it's going to blow over. Where do you stand?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually Mike, it's a great question. I go back to 1985 or the early '80s when i ran the workout group and [indiscernible] our Denver-based energy business up close at that time, and then we saw, of course, the 1 in -- there's been a couple of cycles sinc
componenttext: Actually Mike, it's a great question. I go back to 1985 or the early '80s when i ran the workout group and [indiscernible] our Denver-based energy business up close at that time, and then we saw, of course, the 1 in -- there's been a couple of cycles since that time. And this one's different in a couple of respects. First of all, the economy in the U.S. is more diversified. So the communities, in which energy plays a role, is more diversified. Not true in every community but -- and we look at that. Secondly, companies this time around ranked much more quickly. I think in past corrections, there was more open fire going on for higher prices or a rebound, and so they reacted quickly. And I'd also say this time around, the way companies financed themselves, there was -- there is more private equity and other debt that would be supportive to the bank. So there's been -- there are differences. And I'd say the final thing is the mismatch between supply and demand at the world level is fairly narrow, so there's about 93 million barrels produced a day and about 92 million consumed. So it's a very narrow mismatch and demand seems to still be increasing. So I'm not suggesting that's going to make this problem go away anytime soon. The Saudis are pumping like crazy, so are the Russians. And of course, what's happened with type of oil here in the U.S. But so there are differences. And our people who run on this portfolio for us have seen many or most of those cycles. So everyone is different.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I'd add is there's certainly plenty of give opportunity for market-related agent when one industry suffering and other industries are starting or trying to borrow. But in this instance, the cheap oil is a net stimulative impact on U.S. growth. A
componenttext: One thing I'd add is there's certainly plenty of give opportunity for market-related agent when one industry suffering and other industries are starting or trying to borrow. But in this instance, the cheap oil is a net stimulative impact on U.S. growth. A world come fraud is not beneficial for everybody else in the U.S. Telecom didn't get cheaper, but fuel is getting or gotten cheaper, which is good for consumers and good for other.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'll give you another example. I was with a large builder in the Texas market not long ago and they were talking about the fact that some of what's happening in oil and gas in the field services is making cement more available and workers, and so fo
componenttext: Mike, I'll give you another example. I was with a large builder in the Texas market not long ago and they were talking about the fact that some of what's happening in oil and gas in the field services is making cement more available and workers, and so forth that are important to housing. So not suggesting it happens everywhere, but it's everyone's different.
