componenttext: How much did the GE acquisitions add to EPS this quarter, and what do you expect it to add for the rest of the year?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're not breaking out what it added during the quarter, and what we're saying is we think it'll be modestly accretive for the rest of the year and it's really it's about what it cost to transition people, technology, premises, et cetera, throughout th
componenttext: So we're not breaking out what it added during the quarter, and what we're saying is we think it'll be modestly accretive for the rest of the year and it's really it's about what it cost to transition people, technology, premises, et cetera, throughout the remainder of the year. We'll update that as we move along, and we've got more information about how those costs are actually coming in and being spent. But I'll tell you that the average asset yield for those assets is -- reflects the same kind of loan mix that we have in Wholesale Banking in general, and the expectation once it's -- once they're fully integrated and we finished our process, is that they will carry the same type of efficiency ratio as the average wholesale lending business.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, Mike, in the first quarter, it was a little bit -- a couple moving parts here. We actually, if you will, prefunded the liability side, meaning that we raised debt to fund this and that was on the books at the start of the quarter. And most loans
componenttext: Actually, Mike, in the first quarter, it was a little bit -- a couple moving parts here. We actually, if you will, prefunded the liability side, meaning that we raised debt to fund this and that was on the books at the start of the quarter. And most loans only came on March 1. So there's a lot of stuff going on in the first quarter. But there's 1 month worth of really revenue, if you will.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 3 months of funding, 1 month of revenues. So you'll see the full benefit in the second quarter, I was just wondering if you could size that a little bit more.
componenttext: So 3 months of funding, 1 month of revenues. So you'll see the full benefit in the second quarter, I was just wondering if you could size that a little bit more.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're talking about $30-ish billion worth of assets and the same type of loan yields that we have on average in wholesale, which gets you to a revenue number. What we're not specifically breaking out is what the expense impact is until we understand
componenttext: Well, we're talking about $30-ish billion worth of assets and the same type of loan yields that we have on average in wholesale, which gets you to a revenue number. What we're not specifically breaking out is what the expense impact is until we understand what the full integration expenses are. But you'll see $300 million, $350 million per quarter of NII from the loans and leases themselves.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how much of that did you have in the first quarter, the $300 million, $350 million?
componenttext: And how much of that did you have in the first quarter, the $300 million, $350 million?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so as John said, we had 1 month of the revenue side of it. We had not quite 3 months' worth of the funding cost because we weren't fully funded for those 3 months. But more than 1 month worth of funding cost, how about that?
componenttext: Well, so as John said, we had 1 month of the revenue side of it. We had not quite 3 months' worth of the funding cost because we weren't fully funded for those 3 months. But more than 1 month worth of funding cost, how about that?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then separately, John, did I hear you correctly? You said benefits of falling oil prices offset the cost. I think you said that at the start of the call.
componenttext: Okay. And then separately, John, did I hear you correctly? You said benefits of falling oil prices offset the cost. I think you said that at the start of the call.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Since we're still a net importer of energy, and what's interesting, Mike, is that much of that -- those savings, at the consumer level, had been saved, if you will, but not yet been spent. So not all the savings of the pump [ph] what consumers have d
componenttext: Yes. Since we're still a net importer of energy, and what's interesting, Mike, is that much of that -- those savings, at the consumer level, had been saved, if you will, but not yet been spent. So not all the savings of the pump [ph] what consumers have done and that not exclusively, but they're stating more of that what's happening at a pump [ph] as opposed to spending it.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how do you see that -- I mean, in other words, when oil prices go down, the stock market declines, bank stocks go off. And you're saying that the market's wrong with that. What are you seeing in your business that you think maybe the market has
componenttext: Okay. And how do you see that -- I mean, in other words, when oil prices go down, the stock market declines, bank stocks go off. And you're saying that the market's wrong with that. What are you seeing in your business that you think maybe the market has wrong how they think about oil prices?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is -- I don't -- I've long stopped trying to figure out the market and why bank stocks seemed or stocks generally seem to move in concert with commodity prices, especially oil prices. But be that as it may, the consumer -- much of this economy, 60%, 70
componenttext: It is -- I don't -- I've long stopped trying to figure out the market and why bank stocks seemed or stocks generally seem to move in concert with commodity prices, especially oil prices. But be that as it may, the consumer -- much of this economy, 60%, 70% is consumer-based and retail. And the consumers have never been in better shape. I mentioned in my comments just the [indiscernible] requirement is 15% of their earnings, wages are starting to go up a little bit, and we're seeing savings rates go up. These are some of the strongest savings rates we've seen in some time. I don't know if that's a statement about confidence or whatever, but there's -- it's consumers are benefiting from filling our tank at $1-something a gallon or $2 a gallon versus $3 or $4 and not all of it has been spent.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the last question, can you just give us a sneak preview of the Investor Conference? What do you hope to achieve at the Investor Conference? And do you think you'll have a Director show up again at it?
componenttext: And then the last question, can you just give us a sneak preview of the Investor Conference? What do you hope to achieve at the Investor Conference? And do you think you'll have a Director show up again at it?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Mike, for reminding everybody of that. Steve Sanger, our lead Director, showed up last time. Obviously, we invite our directors and just give me a chance to invite all of you on the 24th of next month, it's a Tuesday. We have an exciting
componenttext: Well, thank you, Mike, for reminding everybody of that. Steve Sanger, our lead Director, showed up last time. Obviously, we invite our directors and just give me a chance to invite all of you on the 24th of next month, it's a Tuesday. We have an exciting day to share with you. We'll get very granular about how we think about distribution, how we think about our businesses. It'll give us a chance to showcase next-generation leaders in the company. So we're looking forward to it. We also will think about guardrails around our 3 big metrics we talked about: ROA, ROE and efficiency ratio. We might talk about that. So it's a bunch of things. And also, everybody talks about FinTechs and clearly, there's a good reason for that. I think our company specifically, and our industry generally, have been innovators for a whole long time. So if we weren't, we'd have stage [indiscernible] on the freeway right now. So -- and we'll talk a little bit about that.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been some recent media attention to the buildout you been doing in some of your advisory and capital markets capacities. And I'm wondering what your or how you view that now in light of, of course, the broader marketplace for those services which
componenttext: There's been some recent media attention to the buildout you been doing in some of your advisory and capital markets capacities. And I'm wondering what your or how you view that now in light of, of course, the broader marketplace for those services which may be under some pressure, and then also the fact that your exposure specifically to the energy industry within those business lines was a bit higher than peers. Is that changing your interest in investment in those areas?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. The pattern's been the same since the merger of Wells and Wachovia to make sure that we've got the right level of capability for capital raising and advisory activity and hedging risk management activity for our corporate and commercial custom
componenttext: Not really. The pattern's been the same since the merger of Wells and Wachovia to make sure that we've got the right level of capability for capital raising and advisory activity and hedging risk management activity for our corporate and commercial customers and other customers of Wells Fargo who need it. We think our risks are well sized. We think our capabilities are well sized. There's always, as you point out, there are things to add here and there. But from a return point of view, from an ability to service our customers point if view, we like the trajectory we've taken. That's why it's so easy to respond pretty quickly when people speculate that we might be thinking about adding an investment bank to our mix or something. That's not what we need. What we need is what we have today and more great people like it to serve more customers. But we're not thinking much differently about it. Our results frankly were, we think they're pretty good in the first quarter. We -- as you say, we've been a leader in capital raising and advisory work for the energy industry for a while. There'll be plenty more need for that as the industry repairs itself. And being in a position to provide that is actually it's good for us. We've got industry-leading positions in a handful of other industries as well, energy is just one of them. But like others, it's a cyclical business, and while it's -- while there's less capital raising going on there right now, there is more going on in other spaces and a lot of advisory work to do. So it fits together very nicely with our Wholesale Bank.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is your intent to continue to add personnel into those business lines?
componenttext: And is your intent to continue to add personnel into those business lines?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. We're always -- as I say, some industries come and go with respect to their capital needs and advisory needs, and so we want to make sure that we've got the right people in positions to do the right thing. We've become an employer of choi
componenttext: Yes, I think so. We're always -- as I say, some industries come and go with respect to their capital needs and advisory needs, and so we want to make sure that we've got the right people in positions to do the right thing. We've become an employer of choice for a lots of those activities. Wells Fargo is a very nice place to work. We've got a great customer franchise who wouldn't want to work here in those businesses compared to some of the places that they might be coming from, and we're always adding good people.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nancy Bush with NAB Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nancy Bush with NAB Research.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I kind of got lost in the hoopla yesterday about the living will, but there was a Reuters news item that says, "Wells Fargo has become significantly more important to the health of the global financial system in the past few years", says a report by
componenttext: John, I kind of got lost in the hoopla yesterday about the living will, but there was a Reuters news item that says, "Wells Fargo has become significantly more important to the health of the global financial system in the past few years", says a report by the Office of Financial Research. And it strikes me with what came out in the resolution letters yesterday that maybe being too important to the global financial system may not be an entirely good thing. And I'm wondering if you feel at this point that your growth or lines of business, your plans for those might be impacted by these findings.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Nancy, we went and looked at that report after that wacky headline hit the tape. And it reported the same thing it reported a year ago, which is that we're #17 among GSIBs in the lowest risk category among globally systemically important banks. S
componenttext: Sure. So Nancy, we went and looked at that report after that wacky headline hit the tape. And it reported the same thing it reported a year ago, which is that we're #17 among GSIBs in the lowest risk category among globally systemically important banks. So there's no basis for that story. We are a big bank. We're globally systemically important and we're used to being measured, but we ended up toward the bottom of that list. So that was a funny conclusion that was drawn. With respect to the feedback that we got in the living will, there are some actionable things that we're going to get right on. But there's nothing about size, about complexity, about the nature of our business model, about our capital, about our liquidity. Really, it was much more around proper governance and maturation of the process, et cetera, which are things that are addressable. So frankly, I don't think we're being criticized by our regulators for the types of things that work their way into the financial press.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: But surely, we're disappointed in the result and all hands on deck here. And we value the feedback we got from the Fed and the FDIC, and we are committed to have a great submission later this year. Nancy, one thing I'd like just to share for a few minutes
componenttext: But surely, we're disappointed in the result and all hands on deck here. And we value the feedback we got from the Fed and the FDIC, and we are committed to have a great submission later this year. Nancy, one thing I'd like just to share for a few minutes. Even though our company has grown significantly organically -- principally organically over the last 7 or 8 years, we have continued to simplify our business. And we're -- we've shed businesses quietly that either didn't have scale for us or provided or had a risk reward relationship that was not consistent. So just -- let me just check off a few I was just thinking while John was talking: we're no longer in the wholesale mortgage business, we're not in the joint venture business, we're not in the reverse mortgage business, we're not in the mortgage consolidation business. We have FHA overlays. So we're not as deep in that business as we had been in the past. We just sold our RCIS insurance business. The direct deposit advance business is no longer here. We're not in the government student lending business, not a lot are. We used it in Wells Fargo Financial business that it's very different today. So yes, we've grown in deposits. We've grown in our corporate loans, et al., and wealth management. All those are kind of things that we're involved in, but a much simpler company today in many respects.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that you've -- if I may ask, you've sort of opened up the Living Will issue. And if I may ask if there are any of this feedback that you've got yesterday that you feel is related to residual issues that are left over from the Wachovia deal. And I thin
componenttext: Now that you've -- if I may ask, you've sort of opened up the Living Will issue. And if I may ask if there are any of this feedback that you've got yesterday that you feel is related to residual issues that are left over from the Wachovia deal. And I think it --I'll just say that as an analyst, it was no great secret in the industry that they were not the best on the reporting side. Are there any tasks left undone that were related to that merger that may have played into your feedback yesterday?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we own this and we're going to get this right.
componenttext: No, we own this and we're going to get this right.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could ask a totally unrelated question, home equity lines of credit seem to be coming back into favor, both at the banks and among consumers. Can you just speak to that business? You've always been important in it. Is it growing now, and how do
componenttext: Okay. If I could ask a totally unrelated question, home equity lines of credit seem to be coming back into favor, both at the banks and among consumers. Can you just speak to that business? You've always been important in it. Is it growing now, and how do you feel about it?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because of the starting point that Wells Fargo has had, the numbers have really only been going in one direction, which is down, down, down. The product that we have today where we do sell it is an amortizing product right out of the gate, so it's very di
componenttext: Because of the starting point that Wells Fargo has had, the numbers have really only been going in one direction, which is down, down, down. The product that we have today where we do sell it is an amortizing product right out of the gate, so it's very different than it was in the old days where it was more just incremental leverage that frankly didn't come down until it might hit some an amortization point in the future. So we certainly offer that amortizing product to our customers, but I don't think you'll see it make a difference in our reported consumer real estate assets. Really on our balance sheet is more about prime jumbo, nonconforming by balance types of loans to prime borrowers.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your final question will come from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Your final question will come from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I've done a little bit of the math when you look at cost of the liabilities over GE and the delay in the assets. It looks like from a net NII standpoint, you've picked up close to $200 million as you move into next quarter just from the balance shee
componenttext: John, I've done a little bit of the math when you look at cost of the liabilities over GE and the delay in the assets. It looks like from a net NII standpoint, you've picked up close to $200 million as you move into next quarter just from the balance sheet side. Just trying to piece it together best I could. Was there any timing effect on the expenses? So as you kind of came in and brought the operations on board, did you have a pretty full run rate on the expense side versus next quarter? So that's my real question is, is there any -- also leverage in a sense that the expenses were already kind of in place for this quarter going into next quarter?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, so the big expense -- the big expenses related are people expenses. The people joined -- the bulk of the people joined on March 1, so in the last month of the quarter. There were some people in the real business that joined at the beginning of the
componenttext: Right, so the big expense -- the big expenses related are people expenses. The people joined -- the bulk of the people joined on March 1, so in the last month of the quarter. There were some people in the real business that joined at the beginning of the year. Another meaningful expense will be depreciation expense on the leased assets that we're picking up and they come over that and that begins when the assets are in place. But importantly, one of the reasons that we're describing this as, as modestly accretive in the year is there's a whole lot of integration expense that needs to occur, including what we're paying for transition services that we're still getting from GE that will shift over to Wells Fargo at some point in the future or different points in the future. And then there's technology work to do. There's some loan file work to do, there's some paperwork to do. There's a lot of things that it takes to make all of those assets Wells Fargo assets in the regulated environment that we're operating in, and we'll pay incremental dollars in the near term to do that. So I'd be hesitant to offer you up a run rate from March that reflects what Q2 and the rest of the year is going to look like.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would you be, on the expense side, isolating those that integration cost, so we can know not the total, but just the integration like you would do it in the other kind of merger? And then -- when we look at the seasonal uptick that we have in the kind of
componenttext: Would you be, on the expense side, isolating those that integration cost, so we can know not the total, but just the integration like you would do it in the other kind of merger? And then -- when we look at the seasonal uptick that we have in the kind of those employee-related expenses, typically don't see kind of a net benefit as they go down because there are other expenses that offset that, but would you see -- would you expect in the core expenses to see somewhat of a rolldown given how high the seasonal expenses were this first quarter? So just 2 things on that side.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I expect that we'll be between 55% and 59% in our efficiency ratio for the rest of the year on the high side of that. And that would capture the change in seasonal expenses. It's a good point that not all of that seasonal comp expense disappear
componenttext: Yes. Well, I expect that we'll be between 55% and 59% in our efficiency ratio for the rest of the year on the high side of that. And that would capture the change in seasonal expenses. It's a good point that not all of that seasonal comp expense disappears and the whole net benefit doesn't come back. We call out in our deck, but there are some other things that have seasonally depressed in the first quarter that pick up in the second quarter, not as big but that are seasonal in that way. And we'll see as we -- we'll see how material it is, but if it becomes appropriate to provide clarity on the GE transition-related expenses, we might consider calling that out. But we haven't begun to yet because we're still developing those expenses. We're still coming into -- we're at the early stage of execution on some of the technology-oriented things that I mentioned and some other chunky early expenses that will start to run off after a bit.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, John, just lastly trying to comment to your head a little bit is as you were looking at the first quarter and you had the gain from selling the crop insurance business and rates were going down, you had so much market disruption. Were you kind o
componenttext: And then, John, just lastly trying to comment to your head a little bit is as you were looking at the first quarter and you had the gain from selling the crop insurance business and rates were going down, you had so much market disruption. Were you kind of thinking in a sense of will I have this gain over here, I don't really feel comfortable putting my liquidity to work because of what's going on in the market. That gives me some kind of breathing room to kind of see where things fall and then start reinvesting in the second quarter, recreating the income that you gave up in the first quarter.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Investing in relatively risk-free assets doesn't produce that much P&L in the quarter that we invest. So it really wasn't much of a trade-off in the first quarter between the gain that reflects this business that we agreed to sell a few quarters ago that
componenttext: Investing in relatively risk-free assets doesn't produce that much P&L in the quarter that we invest. So it really wasn't much of a trade-off in the first quarter between the gain that reflects this business that we agreed to sell a few quarters ago that closed this quarter. It's really -- the threshold issues on reinvestment are more around our capital sensitivity because we're going to be living with the valuation consequences of buying duration at a low rate -- low-yield entry point. And that really is more where the trade-off occurred. So thinking about the whole year impact maybe on interest income but also our OCI sensitivity if rates ultimately back up.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you all for joining us. And also, I want to say thank you to our 268,000 team members for serving our customers and producing $5.5 billion of quarterly earnings. That is just a wonderful result on their behalf. And one more shoutout to all of
componenttext: Okay. Thank you all for joining us. And also, I want to say thank you to our 268,000 team members for serving our customers and producing $5.5 billion of quarterly earnings. That is just a wonderful result on their behalf. And one more shoutout to all of you, please join us on the 24th, Tuesday, May 24 in San Francisco for our Investor Day. Thank you much. Bye-bye.
