componenttextpreview: It can't get much better than that. And on...
componenttext: It can't get much better than that. And on...

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] that number.
componenttext: [indiscernible] that number.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on 1-4 family first mortgage loans, I think we're in the 2 basis point charge-off range right now, which is something that I celebrate when it's happening, but it doesn't feel like a permanent state of affairs.
componenttext: And on 1-4 family first mortgage loans, I think we're in the 2 basis point charge-off range right now, which is something that I celebrate when it's happening, but it doesn't feel like a permanent state of affairs.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a quick follow-up on net interest income. Assuming the rate environment doesn't change much, can you talk a little bit about the puts and takes for growing net interest income? Maybe size up the degree of difficulty of growing that going fo
componenttext: Okay. And then a quick follow-up on net interest income. Assuming the rate environment doesn't change much, can you talk a little bit about the puts and takes for growing net interest income? Maybe size up the degree of difficulty of growing that going forward. And then just on liquidity, cash on the balance sheet, when we look at that fed fund sold like roughly $300 billion, is there any way for us to kind of get a sense of how much that might be redeployable versus how much is needed to meet the requirements of LCR and other kind of regulatory needs to hold liquidity?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's not much limitation on the redeployment of that into HQLA while still satisfying the liquidity coverage ratio. So it really gets back to the when is the right time and how much at that time if you're just, for example, buying treasuries be
componenttext: Yes. So there's not much limitation on the redeployment of that into HQLA while still satisfying the liquidity coverage ratio. So it really gets back to the when is the right time and how much at that time if you're just, for example, buying treasuries because of the capital implications that it creates by putting more AFS securities on the books. You're that much more exposed to a backup. So there's a trade-off there. For non-HQLA, the limitations are different because you're losing the benefit of that liquidity. And we've continued to dimension the ability to move out of cash or HQLA and into risk assets, all things being equal, based on a snapshot as tens of billions of dollars of activity. You saw what we did last year when we -- or earlier this year as we were sizing up, taking the GE assets under their book -- our books. We actually went out and did a little bit of incremental funding in the marketplace to have that liquidity set aside. And now we're allowing that to run off. It was relatively short term. But it makes sense for us to have ready access to something -- some -- call it $200 billion worth of instant liquidity at any point in time. That's given our size, given our risk profile and given our stress cases. Is that helpful?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just the broader comment about just kind of degree of difficulty of growing NII overall in this environment?
componenttext: Yes. And just the broader comment about just kind of degree of difficulty of growing NII overall in this environment?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it is harder to grow net interest income in a lower-rate environment than otherwise, which is obvious. The short end of the curve is one thing, but this move down in 7 years and out is just as hard and just as meaningful because of the redeploy
componenttext: Yes. Well, it is harder to grow net interest income in a lower-rate environment than otherwise, which is obvious. The short end of the curve is one thing, but this move down in 7 years and out is just as hard and just as meaningful because of the redeployment. So it's still our plan and our goal. And what we're telling you is that we intend to grow net interest income even if there are no rate moves. And we're doing it by adding earning -- by redeploying cash into HQLA and other earning assets, by looking everywhere for customers where we can make quality loans. And those are the big items. So it's our plan; it's our effort; it's what we're all working towards, but it's harder.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, the biggest influence that Brexit had on our company was not on, frankly, a direct impact on the way we do business or customers or anything like that. It really was the big move down in long-term rates.
componenttext: And John, the biggest influence that Brexit had on our company was not on, frankly, a direct impact on the way we do business or customers or anything like that. It really was the big move down in long-term rates.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One other thing to say is it's a great time to be a borrower; it's a great time to be one of our customers. The mortgage business is one obvious place to look for the origination fee generation or gain generation. But across the board, I would expect
componenttext: Yes. One other thing to say is it's a great time to be a borrower; it's a great time to be one of our customers. The mortgage business is one obvious place to look for the origination fee generation or gain generation. But across the board, I would expect more -- everything is more affordable on a financed basis. So it helps.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Barker with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: In regards to your servicing results inputs in the mortgage bank, were there any changes in the way you hedged that asset this quarter? Or was there something specific around the rate curve and the movement in the yield curve in the second quarter versus
componenttext: In regards to your servicing results inputs in the mortgage bank, were there any changes in the way you hedged that asset this quarter? Or was there something specific around the rate curve and the movement in the yield curve in the second quarter versus the first quarter that would have caused the hedging gains to be less than expected?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good question. There wasn't really any change to the hedging approach. And our hedging results, strictly speaking, accomplished what they were intended to. There were just -- there were a handful of items that went, call it, in our favor in th
componenttext: Yes. It's a good question. There wasn't really any change to the hedging approach. And our hedging results, strictly speaking, accomplished what they were intended to. There were just -- there were a handful of items that went, call it, in our favor in the first quarter that were negatives in the second quarter. And some of them are input -- are just model inputs in terms of how the MSR valuation calculation works. Some of it, obviously, was just lower servicing fees. That's not a hedging outcome, but it contributed to the net servicing benefits, thanks to Speed it Up [ph]. Of course, we're getting more servicing called away from us. Even as we originate at this pace, there's more servicing getting called away from us as others do -- as others originate rapidly as well. So I would expect that to normalize, and I would think about that also as something more along the lines of a multi-quarter average. And one other item I'd point out is that the unreimbursed servicing cost was a net drag -- an incremental net drag this quarter as well. That's mostly around FHA activity.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: In regards to the FHA activity, what is the headwind that you're seeing from unreimbursed insurance claims this quarter? Or how would you look at, like, the run rate from that line item?
componenttext: In regards to the FHA activity, what is the headwind that you're seeing from unreimbursed insurance claims this quarter? Or how would you look at, like, the run rate from that line item?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're talking about a couple hundred million dollars of unreimbursed direct cost in the second quarter. And the run rate is probably half of that, looking back over the last several quarters.
componenttext: Well, I think we're talking about a couple hundred million dollars of unreimbursed direct cost in the second quarter. And the run rate is probably half of that, looking back over the last several quarters.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in regards to the introduction of yourFirstMortgage, have you seen an incremental increase in your overall mortgage originations from the introduction of that product? Or would you expect that to accelerate on a go-forward basis?
componenttext: Okay. And in regards to the introduction of yourFirstMortgage, have you seen an incremental increase in your overall mortgage originations from the introduction of that product? Or would you expect that to accelerate on a go-forward basis?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well -- so there's an increase, all things being equal, on the agency side of things. But many of those borrowers might have been FHA-eligible borrowers prior to the introduction of that program. So in some sense, we're shifting origination from one progr
componenttext: Well -- so there's an increase, all things being equal, on the agency side of things. But many of those borrowers might have been FHA-eligible borrowers prior to the introduction of that program. So in some sense, we're shifting origination from one program to another. It's a -- we think it's a very high-quality program. It's -- the way we've described it and constructed it, it's never worse for a customer and it's often better for a customer because it's got -- there's a different approach to MI that's more borrower friendly. So there should be more availability for it, and it should help grow originations over time. And as we mentioned, it's particularly valuable to us because it gives access to mortgage credit to low- and middle-income borrowers and first-time homebuyers who are people that we're really trying to serve.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Paul Miller with FBR.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Paul Miller with FBR.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the follow-up to Kevin's questions on yourFirstMortgage, is this very similar to what an FHA product put outside of the FHA arena to a Fannie and Freddie product, i.e., is it low-FICO, low-downpayment-type loans?
componenttext: On the follow-up to Kevin's questions on yourFirstMortgage, is this very similar to what an FHA product put outside of the FHA arena to a Fannie and Freddie product, i.e., is it low-FICO, low-downpayment-type loans?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's lower downpayment. Actually, the first part of your question is this is an agency program. This is a Wells Fargo and Fannie program. It is geared to serve the first-time homebuyer and the low- and middle-income homebuyers, so there is some over
componenttext: Well, it's lower downpayment. Actually, the first part of your question is this is an agency program. This is a Wells Fargo and Fannie program. It is geared to serve the first-time homebuyer and the low- and middle-income homebuyers, so there is some overlap with people that the FHA might be serving, as I mentioned. And it is built around a lower initial downpayment to make it easier for those people to access credit. I wouldn't describe it as a -- predominantly, the lower FICO, lower credit quality, but more of a structured for people who have lower downpayment available.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Paul, it really looks at those first-time homebuyers especially, so it really looks to serve that market, many times have a lower downpayment available.
componenttext: Yes. And Paul, it really looks at those first-time homebuyers especially, so it really looks to serve that market, many times have a lower downpayment available.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this product will be sold -- I mean, either sold or wrapped by Ginnie Mae guarantees?
componenttext: And this product will be sold -- I mean, either sold or wrapped by Ginnie Mae guarantees?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's agency mortgage production, so it doesn't look any different than our books. It goes right into agency security. So there's no different risk profile on our books. And frankly, one of the reasons that the program makes so much sense for us is because
componenttext: It's agency mortgage production, so it doesn't look any different than our books. It goes right into agency security. So there's no different risk profile on our books. And frankly, one of the reasons that the program makes so much sense for us is because we have such a commercial relationship with Fannie in terms of knowing what our risks are, what their risks are and when those risks pass. And that's very helpful.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I don't know if you disclose this or not, but what -- do you guys know what your recapture rate is on your refis right now on your book? And you have one of the biggest books out there under MSR. Are you able to recapture a lot of those refis?
componenttext: Okay. And I don't know if you disclose this or not, but what -- do you guys know what your recapture rate is on your refis right now on your book? And you have one of the biggest books out there under MSR. Are you able to recapture a lot of those refis?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do capture a lot of our refis. I don't think we disclose the capture rate. We probably do disclose our market share both in origination and in servicing. I don't have them at my fingertips, but we'll come back to you with the most recent specifics.
componenttext: So we do capture a lot of our refis. I don't think we disclose the capture rate. We probably do disclose our market share both in origination and in servicing. I don't have them at my fingertips, but we'll come back to you with the most recent specifics. And that relationship will help you to -- when there's obviously other things going on there because a lot of mortgage origination is not refi activity. But that might be helpful.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Paul, just one quick thing. We are recapturing less today, as John mentioned, because some products were no longer in. So some of that refinances is refinancing away from us where we would have captured more in the past some of the higher-risk categor
componenttext: But Paul, just one quick thing. We are recapturing less today, as John mentioned, because some products were no longer in. So some of that refinances is refinancing away from us where we would have captured more in the past some of the higher-risk categories.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: To follow up on expenses, a lot of talk earlier about the investment spend, the risk, the compliance, obviously, growth areas and then eventually getting the payback on that. As we think about just the pace of investment spend and that relationship of kin
componenttext: To follow up on expenses, a lot of talk earlier about the investment spend, the risk, the compliance, obviously, growth areas and then eventually getting the payback on that. As we think about just the pace of investment spend and that relationship of kind of getting it back on your side, what inning are we in, in terms of still ramping on the investment and still waiting on the payoff?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say we're in the middle innings of the investment. We'll be doing -- we've been doing it for a few years. We'll be doing it for a few more years, I'm sure, and we'll always be innovating. But in some cases, we've -- we're getting the payback. Yo
componenttext: Well, I'd say we're in the middle innings of the investment. We'll be doing -- we've been doing it for a few years. We'll be doing it for a few more years, I'm sure, and we'll always be innovating. But in some cases, we've -- we're getting the payback. You saw at Investor Day the moves that we made toward more of a paperless store, and we talked about the specifics in terms of what the benefit is of taking paper, labor, storage, transportation out of stores. And that's happened; that's in our run rate. A lot of the digital and mobile migration that we have of customer activity is taking personal interactions out of those types of transactions, is taking paper out for sure. And those benefits feed right into the run rate as they happen. John was mentioning the initial investment in build to create some of these new programs in compliance and risk management, for example, and the fact that once they're highly effective and repeatable, then there's an opportunity to automate, to streamline and to learn from how we got there and to make them more efficient. I'd say those opportunities are -- we're always learning, but they're probably a little bit more in the future. And then with it, who knows where we'll be going with the increase in mobility, et cetera? And my sense is we're just going to keep benefiting customers benefit, on the one hand; but from an expense perspective, we'll keep benefiting as well. I'd point out the P2P activity as another place where we're taking checks out, taking cash handling out, increasing customer service but doing it at a lower cost to serve. So there's a lot to that.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you still at a point where you're increasing overall investment spend? Or are you able to remix some of that so that it's still at a high level but not necessarily going up?
componenttext: Are you still at a point where you're increasing overall investment spend? Or are you able to remix some of that so that it's still at a high level but not necessarily going up?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's still going up a little bit. We've been doing that while taking expense out of our standard run rate in order to accommodate it while staying within our 55% to 59%. So -- and as the nature of mobile first and technological solutions first occ
componenttext: I think it's still going up a little bit. We've been doing that while taking expense out of our standard run rate in order to accommodate it while staying within our 55% to 59%. So -- and as the nature of mobile first and technological solutions first occurs, we're always going to be spending at a high level. We'll just keep [indiscernible] for innovative types of activities, and we'll keep doing what we're doing at taking expense out of our business as usual.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just separately, you mentioned in the press release about the higher amortization on the mortgage bond book, which makes sense given the sharp drop in the rate. But do you have the figures in terms of how much it was this quarter versus last? And
componenttext: And then just separately, you mentioned in the press release about the higher amortization on the mortgage bond book, which makes sense given the sharp drop in the rate. But do you have the figures in terms of how much it was this quarter versus last? And remind us how your strategy or approach there is. Is there like a mark-to-market? Or is there a smoothing effect? One of your peers has what feels like a mark-to-market impact so you take a hit up-front. Some other peers smooth out a little bit more. Remind us how your approach is.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What I would point out is that we're amortizing premiums on mortgage securities in particular that are highly prepayment sensitive. And in this quarter, the net interest margin or net interest dollars' negative impact of getting premium book value bo
componenttext: Yes. What I would point out is that we're amortizing premiums on mortgage securities in particular that are highly prepayment sensitive. And in this quarter, the net interest margin or net interest dollars' negative impact of getting premium book value bonds called away at par was -- I think the number is $100 million. I'm confirming it's $100 million. So that's one way of thinking about it. So we put a mortgage security under a premium. We amortized that premium over an expected life with an expected CPR. Things come in faster, and we have to write off the remaining premium when it happens. This quarter, that impact was $100 million.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you have that for last quarter?
componenttext: And do you have that for last quarter?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think I do handy, but it wasn't $100 million. So less.
componenttext: I don't think I do handy, but it wasn't $100 million. So less.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just 2 quick ones on credit. First, in auto lending, you mentioned the Manheim is up a little bit, but severities are up a little bit as well. What's driving that? I know it's not you; it's the number of bullets driving that disconnect.
componenttext: Maybe just 2 quick ones on credit. First, in auto lending, you mentioned the Manheim is up a little bit, but severities are up a little bit as well. What's driving that? I know it's not you; it's the number of bullets driving that disconnect.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Manheim is up a little bit and was up in each of the last few months. And I think as we've said, we have an expectation that, that can't go on forever. And that's part of why we would say that we expect future losses to be a little bit more normal in that
componenttext: Manheim is up a little bit and was up in each of the last few months. And I think as we've said, we have an expectation that, that can't go on forever. And that's part of why we would say that we expect future losses to be a little bit more normal in that business than what's been happening. The -- any change in severity is really just the change in the mix, the repo activity, the circumstances of what's been coming. And I don't think there's a systematic reason for it.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, I would just add that there's been a really strong new car sales the last couple of years. Some of those go out in lease programs and they come off leased. So our guess is that there'll be more late-model used cars on the market, put pressure o
componenttext: And Brian, I would just add that there's been a really strong new car sales the last couple of years. Some of those go out in lease programs and they come off leased. So our guess is that there'll be more late-model used cars on the market, put pressure on Manheim on the other hand, which could cause a normalization in losses. On the other hand, that's really where we play and where we have a lot of market expertise. So it's a bit of an offset.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on Commercial Real Estate. I mean, I guess, if I think about both your commentary on data as well as, like, what the OCC is saying, et cetera, there's just kind of general concern around underwriting standards. But at the same time, the current d
componenttext: And then on Commercial Real Estate. I mean, I guess, if I think about both your commentary on data as well as, like, what the OCC is saying, et cetera, there's just kind of general concern around underwriting standards. But at the same time, the current data around loan growth is pretty good, and on charge-offs, it's kind of bouncing between 0 and net recoveries. So it's about as good as it can get. How are you thinking about the Commercial Real Estate cycle now? Is it just kind of pockets of concern? Or is there a concern that there is maybe a more broad-based turn on the horizon or how you kind of think [indiscernible] the concerns around underwriting standards versus the very good numbers today?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I would say that our underwriting approach to Commercial Real Estate tends to be at the conservative end of the spectrum and where we have a reputation often for better, sometimes to the chagrin of customers for approaching it that way, which is -
componenttext: Yes. So I would say that our underwriting approach to Commercial Real Estate tends to be at the conservative end of the spectrum and where we have a reputation often for better, sometimes to the chagrin of customers for approaching it that way, which is -- which helps us well through cycles. This is -- as you're alluding to, this is a very cyclical business. It is regional and local. It is property type by property type. There are some areas and some property types where values have been elevated because people have been willing to accept really, really low returns on their invested capital, and that creates one sort of outcome. And then there are others where there is just a lot of supply that's coming on, has come on and has to be absorbed. Now that creates a different dynamic. We're seeing that. We have seen that in some multifamily or luxury single-family from market to market. And that -- in that market, those dynamics have to play out where that gets absorbed at some clearing price. We're taking the same approach that we always have. We're sort of a relatively low loan-to-value lender. We look very hard at in-place cash flow. We have a lot of incremental borrower guarantees and supplemental protections in our bigger Commercial Real Estate types of financings. And that's -- it's always been true. So I'm sure when the cycle turns, there'll be either property types or geographies where -- that do better or worse. But we're not taking a big change. We're not seeing a big sea change. Our originations have actually -- have been slower. Certainly, we're slower before we bought the seasoned GE portfolio, the organic activity because of the competitive environment and because of the market circumstances caused us to slow down there somewhat.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the investment portfolio. John, you had mentioned that you had added a lot of securities this quarter before the rate change, and looks like you did it mostly in the agency MBS and the held to maturity. And I'm just wondering, given that it
componenttext: A question on the investment portfolio. John, you had mentioned that you had added a lot of securities this quarter before the rate change, and looks like you did it mostly in the agency MBS and the held to maturity. And I'm just wondering, given that it looks like that average yield was 1.90% or below given that's where the average are, how are you thinking about continuing to build the securities book versus potentially keeping more of your originated production where you can get a 3% handle still versus maybe a 1.5% in the securities book? So what's your trade-off on interest rate risk versus credit risk, I guess? And do your -- does your philosophy change given where we are in the environment at all?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good question, and it's analysis that we conduct. We've -- as I had mentioned earlier, we've been continuing to sell all of our conforming production. There's -- there are limited but not -- but some benefits -- limited liquidity attribution,
componenttext: Yes. It's a good question, and it's analysis that we conduct. We've -- as I had mentioned earlier, we've been continuing to sell all of our conforming production. There's -- there are limited but not -- but some benefits -- limited liquidity attribution, but some benefits to agency mortgage securities, but less so or not so with loans. So that's part of that determination. There's a different risk profile for carrying loans on the books, obviously, versus guaranteed pass-throughs. That's part of the analysis. We have a reasonably large allocation to single-family whole loan and real estate -- residential real estate today because of our jumbo portfolio, which we continue to want to make room for as we serve those customers going forward. So all those things sort of fit together in our risk appetite and have -- setting the ALCO considerations aside. But just from how much is enough and what type of risk do you need on your books, we follow the path that we followed, which isn't to say that, if circumstances change or persisted and the allocation opportunities look a little bit different, we wouldn't modify our conclusion, but that's where we've gotten thus far.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just second question on Commercial Real Estate brokerage just within the other fees category. It's been a good business for you historically. It looks like it's gotten a little softer. Is that purposeful change in how you're doing the busin
componenttext: Okay. And then just second question on Commercial Real Estate brokerage just within the other fees category. It's been a good business for you historically. It looks like it's gotten a little softer. Is that purposeful change in how you're doing the business? Or is it just the environment? Any color there would be great.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's cyclical. It's a great business for us. We're the best, frankly, in that business, and there's a lot of knock-on benefit in terms of the financing that we do, investment banking that we do for those customers. But it is cyclical and it will follow pa
componenttext: It's cyclical. It's a great business for us. We're the best, frankly, in that business, and there's a lot of knock-on benefit in terms of the financing that we do, investment banking that we do for those customers. But it is cyclical and it will follow patterns like the ones that we just talked about in terms of what's going on in different markets. That business is interesting because it's got something for bullish times in Commercial Real Estate. That's got something for bearish times in Commercial Real Estate because the same team is involved in helping to find liquidity for properties and financing for properties when things aren't going well in markets and when investors are going the other way. So we like it, but it's a little bit harder to forecast because it doesn't just trend up over time; it moves around. But it's been a great performer for the last couple of years.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's no change in terms of how you're approaching it. It's just a little bit of an air pocket.
componenttext: So there's no change in terms of how you're approaching it. It's just a little bit of an air pocket.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just the normal volatility and what's happening in that business. No change.
componenttext: It's just the normal volatility and what's happening in that business. No change.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Joe Morford with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Joe Morford with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: The C&I growth seemed a bit softer this quarter, particularly relative to the pace you saw through much of last year. Is there anything to that besides maybe some impact from energy? And just how, in general, do you feel business owner confidence is these
componenttext: The C&I growth seemed a bit softer this quarter, particularly relative to the pace you saw through much of last year. Is there anything to that besides maybe some impact from energy? And just how, in general, do you feel business owner confidence is these days, particularly given some of the uncertainties like Brexit and the upcoming election?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure what would inspire a marginal business owner confidence in this environment. I mean, it's about the same as it has been recently, probably a little bit less certainty given what's going on around the world, but I wouldn't -- I don't think of
componenttext: I'm not sure what would inspire a marginal business owner confidence in this environment. I mean, it's about the same as it has been recently, probably a little bit less certainty given what's going on around the world, but I wouldn't -- I don't think of that as having a meaningful impact on the quarter's organic C&I loan growth. It's competitive and we're out there competing. There's some amount of capital formation around CapEx and expansion and other projects; not as much as there would be if we were in a more vibrant overall economic environment. There's actually a little more happening in energy today than there was over the last several quarters, more capital being raised, more assets are changing hands [indiscernible] to some financing opportunities. So I would think of it more as a season or a short period of time to measure against. Nothing to worry there.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you also talked earlier about being disciplined on expenses and getting paper and transactions out of the stores. But kind of more broadly speaking, how are you currently thinking about the overall retail distribution network, particularly
componenttext: Okay. And then you also talked earlier about being disciplined on expenses and getting paper and transactions out of the stores. But kind of more broadly speaking, how are you currently thinking about the overall retail distribution network, particularly given the growth in Mobile Banking? If you're considering moving more aggressively or transitioning to the small and neighborhood stores or perhaps maybe don't need as much density in certain markets, it can reduce the overall footprint. What's the update there?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Joe, I think that's an interesting question. We continue to look at that, and we're not oblivious to the changes going on. As you suggest, the mobile offerings are our fastest-growing channel now. 18 million of our 20-some million households now have
componenttext: Yes. Joe, I think that's an interesting question. We continue to look at that, and we're not oblivious to the changes going on. As you suggest, the mobile offerings are our fastest-growing channel now. 18 million of our 20-some million households now have -- use that and sometimes -- most times as their dominant channel. So we continue to think about that. Our philosophy has been -- or continuing to be we want to serve customers when we're in holiday want to be served. We don't want to drive them some place to our benefit. We want to provide for their benefit. That being said, that's a big area of -- we continue to look at as we innovate and we see customers change their behaviors.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to make it easier for them to do business with us in other channels as well. And if they change their behavior, then we'll react to that.
componenttext: We're going to make it easier for them to do business with us in other channels as well. And if they change their behavior, then we'll react to that.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll react to it and that -- those could have some meaningful impacts on it.
componenttext: We'll react to it and that -- those could have some meaningful impacts on it.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll try to be quick given the length of the call here, but I am going to beat the dead horse here on the expense topic. But I know -- and I appreciate the color you gave on the levers that you can pull given the -- what we're seeing on the top line side
componenttext: I'll try to be quick given the length of the call here, but I am going to beat the dead horse here on the expense topic. But I know -- and I appreciate the color you gave on the levers that you can pull given the -- what we're seeing on the top line side here. Now what I'm trying to just understand is like what do we need to see, maybe it's in terms of where rates go or overall top line pressure, for you to start to really pull those levers more aggressively? And again, maybe it's around expenses. And also longer term, is the goal just to keep the efficiency ratio? Are you okay with that high end of that range even through '17 if this top line pressure persists from the curve? Or do you, at some point, look to get to the middle of that range again?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's how we look at expenses. We look at this company -- in fact, on Wednesday, we had our 164th birthday, and we look at this company from a long-term perspective. We've always been thoughtful about how we spend our shareholders' money. We're the stewa
componenttext: Here's how we look at expenses. We look at this company -- in fact, on Wednesday, we had our 164th birthday, and we look at this company from a long-term perspective. We've always been thoughtful about how we spend our shareholders' money. We're the stewards of your capital and their capital. And surely, a longer -- a lower-for-longer scenario puts pressure on everything that we do. But we're going to continue to make those investments that we believe are good, long-term investments to help customers succeed financially. That being said, I do think we're at a point in time where there are some opportunities that -- because of changing customer behaviors. So we will -- but we're not going to do something that's still going to be short term, bright and long-term dull, if you will, just because of pressure on the revenue side or the earnings side. Just assume that we're going to continue to work really hard on making investments and also maturing systems, taking out costs that don't add value. In other words, think of either of maximizing or monetizing our scale.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. And then just if rates -- if we only see another 25 basis points next year and that's it, is it fair to assume that you are in that upper range still of the efficiency ratio?
componenttext: Got it. Got it. And then just if rates -- if we only see another 25 basis points next year and that's it, is it fair to assume that you are in that upper range still of the efficiency ratio?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we probably are. Yes.
componenttext: I think we probably are. Yes.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Which, still, is a world-class range.
componenttext: Which, still, is a world-class range.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and it's -- and don't take for granted how hard one has to work to operate at 58% efficiency ratio. There's a lot that has to happen to stay there while we're spending the money that we're spending to innovate and improve ourselves from a compliance,
componenttext: Yes, and it's -- and don't take for granted how hard one has to work to operate at 58% efficiency ratio. There's a lot that has to happen to stay there while we're spending the money that we're spending to innovate and improve ourselves from a compliance, risk management and other perspective.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: One narrow question and then perhaps one broader one. On the -- on your servicing income, and I'm looking at the data on Page 40 of the release, your servicing fees are down year-over-year by, in order of magnitude, something like 20%, but your servicing
componenttext: One narrow question and then perhaps one broader one. On the -- on your servicing income, and I'm looking at the data on Page 40 of the release, your servicing fees are down year-over-year by, in order of magnitude, something like 20%, but your servicing portfolio is only down about 3%. What's the dynamic there on the servicing income?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there are older categories of loan product that are running off that might have different per-pound fees associated with them. There's hot -- there's different categories of unreimbursed servicing expense that get netted against those servicing fees. A
componenttext: So there are older categories of loan product that are running off that might have different per-pound fees associated with them. There's hot -- there's different categories of unreimbursed servicing expense that get netted against those servicing fees. And I mentioned we're up $100 million, I think, in this quarter, which contributes to the delta between last year and this year -- or that a quarter a year ago and this quarter. But the servicing book has been getting smaller as we've walked away from higher-risk activities, et cetera and focused more on core -- today's core agency mortgage origination. So that phenomena is something to grapple with when thinking about how that performs over the coming couple of years as augmented by how successful we are on the origination side and growing new servicing assets as well.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: But does the pace of change -- I guess, does the pace of change at all because of the, presumably, many of the legacy assets are now being refi-ed away and newer assets made look more like legacy assets in terms of servicing rate?
componenttext: But does the pace of change -- I guess, does the pace of change at all because of the, presumably, many of the legacy assets are now being refi-ed away and newer assets made look more like legacy assets in terms of servicing rate?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what changes is the cost of service because we're working through the -- we've had higher foreclosed and workout expenses over time. There's labor. There's extra compliance. There's a lot going on. The standards are still -- the new standard
componenttext: Well, I think what changes is the cost of service because we're working through the -- we've had higher foreclosed and workout expenses over time. There's labor. There's extra compliance. There's a lot going on. The standards are still -- the new standards are as high as they've ever been, but incidents will be going down over time. So my sense is that, that should improve, which should be some scale there. And perhaps it's true also that per-pound revenue per loan revenue scales into today's run rate and each -- with each new $1 billion worth of servicing that we add to the book, it doesn't pay the same servicing revenue as a legacy $1 billion. But you'll watch that move slowly over time.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I can just step back for a moment, your earnings power for the past several years now has been running just above $4. And of course, this current quarter has sort affirmed that run rate. And the consensus for next year is closer to $4.30. And
componenttext: And then if I can just step back for a moment, your earnings power for the past several years now has been running just above $4. And of course, this current quarter has sort affirmed that run rate. And the consensus for next year is closer to $4.30. And I'm not asking you to specifically forecast, but could you help us understand, like, what bridges that increase in earnings power? Presumably, rates might be some of it, but is there -- the balance sheet continues to grow. But in the absence of rates, would that figure be achievable? Or are we more in a trend line?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a lot of unknowns in that question, and we're not giving guidance next year. But as was mentioned earlier by Erika in terms of what might happen or what has to happen as we grow in the future, some -- it will be earning asset growth, loans a
componenttext: Well, there's a lot of unknowns in that question, and we're not giving guidance next year. But as was mentioned earlier by Erika in terms of what might happen or what has to happen as we grow in the future, some -- it will be earning asset growth, loans and investments; it will be what we -- how efficient we are on the expense side of things; and then the whole spectrum of noninterest income generating possibilities. There's a lot of strength in a number of those line items.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: General Electric.
componenttext: General Electric.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016

So it's doing more with customers and generating more lending opportunity, more noninterest income opportunity and executing along those lines. It's a lot of work.

We're in a real economy. We do have 90 different businesses. We serve customers broadly and deeply, and I don't think I'd want any other model for this environment.

componenttextpreview: ;John, what I was wanting to kind of drill down to is if you think about mortgage refinance, the way you've got accounting set up where you recognize at close and the way that the servicing valuations get hit almost instantaneously when rates fall, you
componenttext:
;
John, what I was wanting to kind of drill down to is if you think about mortgage refinance, the way you've got accounting set up where you recognize at close and the way that the servicing valuations get hit almost instantaneously when rates fall, you typically have a pressure quarter when refinance kicks in followed by more favorable outcomes as you move forward. So I just wanted to focus on that kind of contrast and make sure that I'm still thinking about that right as it's been kind of built in the past.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016

componenttext: I think you probably are.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the only thing I was going to add as a follow-up is if you think about what you were just responding to, the one thing that I think you left out was the fact that share repurchase will reduce the shares outstanding by about half of that growth th
componenttext: And then the only thing I was going to add as a follow-up is if you think about what you were just responding to, the one thing that I think you left out was the fact that share repurchase will reduce the shares outstanding by about half of that growth that was just highlighted. So capital announcements has a big part of what would generate any incremental growth as if net income was absolutely flat from this point forward.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And 2 -- 1 larger question and 2 small ones. The commentary on the oil and gas portfolio and the trends there seems to be a little bit different than what we heard from JPMorgan Chase yesterday and U.S. Bancorp earlier this morning, where they seem to be
componenttext: And 2 -- 1 larger question and 2 small ones. The commentary on the oil and gas portfolio and the trends there seems to be a little bit different than what we heard from JPMorgan Chase yesterday and U.S. Bancorp earlier this morning, where they seem to be a little less equivocal in the trends. And it looks like you had a big addition in nonaccruals, but you didn't add to the reserve for the portfolio. Yesterday, Jamie Dimon talked about the companies in their portfolio having greater access to other financing. That seemed to be -- your trends or commentary was a little different than that. Can you just -- I mean, are there differences in your oil and gas portfolio? Or are you just being cautious here?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say both. There are probably differences. We have a big broad spectrum of upstream, midstream and services companies that includes a lot of middle-market companies, which our entire wholesale portfolio does. So their portfolios are probably different.
componenttext: I'd say both. There are probably differences. We have a big broad spectrum of upstream, midstream and services companies that includes a lot of middle-market companies, which our entire wholesale portfolio does. So their portfolios are probably different. We are generally cautious, however. I guess, I'd point out that our criticized assets and some there in energy are down by $1.7 billion. Within that, we moved more into nonperforming in the quarter, which we had expected to do in our outlook as we sat here a quarter ago, which is why our reserve didn't have to go up in connection with that. I think we're just a little -- we're a little -- it's a little premature to declare victory because prices are hovering in crude in the $40s. And who knows what the next couple of quarters brings? And we don't want to get ahead of ourselves there. We're performing great with 39 basis points of loss all in with these levels. And so there's no point in declaring victory. We would agree -- if I didn't mention that, it was an oversight. There is a lot more access to capital among energy companies today, all forms. Loans, high yield, high grade and equity were busier in the second quarter than they have been in a while. There are more assets changing hands. Things are freeing up a little bit. And that's going to help with resolutions. And we think we've captured the benefit of that in our analysis for what our exposures are, but it's true. And it was less true a couple of quarters ago.

componenttext: Okay. And just one final question. John Stumpf, you raised the dividend what, $0.02, I guess, what, last quarter, and you're sort of at the 37% payout ratio, et cetera, et cetera. When would be the next regular dividend meeting where you would consider a more meaningful dividend increase? And given that your stock is one of the highest yielding in the group, is that necessary at this point?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we increased $0.005, right, from $0.375 to $0.38. And I would remind, as John did, that -- and you just suggested that if you take $0.38 and divide that by $1.01, you get a number that is -- that we're proud about. We just went through our CCAR proc
componenttext: Well, we increased $0.005, right, from $0.375 to $0.38. And I would remind, as John did, that -- and you just suggested that if you take $0.38 and divide that by $1.01, you get a number that is -- that we're proud about. We just went through our CCAR process, and I hope you would agree and I know our investors appreciate the fact that we are shareholder friendly. We have -- of the big banks, or of the Giuseppes, we are a leader in returning capital. So dividends are important. It speaks to the confidence of our -- of how we run the company and the earnings momentum that we have. On the other hand, buybacks are also important. So they're both in there, and we -- and the question you asked, we think about that a lot. So -- and we will continue to put all of our emphasis on running a really great business and returning as much capital as we can, and we should -- and people should think about the 55% to 75% range.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. When you look at the balance sheet, when you look at the kind of on the liability side of the balance sheet, if you look at it year-on-year, you've seen deposits up $60 billion, where most of the funding comes from short-term borrow
componenttext: Just a quick question. When you look at the balance sheet, when you look at the kind of on the liability side of the balance sheet, if you look at it year-on-year, you've seen deposits up $60 billion, where most of the funding comes from short-term borrowings and long-term debt. So is there something changing in the depositor base? Are depositors becoming more rate sensitive? And that's why you're not seeing the deposit growth that you once were, especially this quarter where it's a little bit about $4 billion on end of period for total deposits. Yes, just wondering if there's like a change in the depositors there.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If there's anything specific, I'd say it's among wholesale customers. I think retail deposits grew by 8% year-over-year and the total grew by 4%, and the balance is coming from wholesale customers who are a little bit more price sensitive. And in the
componenttext: Yes. If there's anything specific, I'd say it's among wholesale customers. I think retail deposits grew by 8% year-over-year and the total grew by 4%, and the balance is coming from wholesale customers who are a little bit more price sensitive. And in the wake of the 25 basis point move in December, there are some deposits that we paid a little bit more for in wholesale and some that we didn't and some that have better liquidity value and some that have worse. And this is how that's shaking out. You pointed out that there's been some more wholesale funding on the liability side. We went out and put on some shortish term. I think it shows up as long term because it's beyond a year, but shortish-term financing to make sure we had funding in place for the GE assets as they came on. Some of that will roll off; some of that we might hang on to for a while, but it's a mix. And then as you also pointed out, we are out there marching along the TLAC implementation path. And we will be over the course of the next several years. And that will add to that portion of liability stack.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, we love all of our deposits and depositors. But if you look at -- as John mentioned, if you look at the most core of our core deposits, that would be retail and especially retail transaction deposits, savings account, checking accounts. And if you
componenttext:
Brian, we love all of our deposits and depositors. But if you look at -- as John mentioned, if you look at the most core of our core deposits, that would be retail and especially retail transaction deposits, savings account, checking accounts. And if you look at our net primary, which is what people love out of those accounts, you look at that growth and you look at the growth on the retail side. It's been world-class for us, so -- and that continues to march along.
Well, I know we ran over, but I want to thank all of you for joining us today and your interest in Wells Fargo and your questions. So also, I want to thank all of our 265,000-plus team members for a great quarter. Thank you much. See you next quarter. Bye-bye.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 15, 2016
