componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John McDonald with Bernstein.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I know it's early here, but maybe you could talk about what factors are you going to be balancing when you redesign the sales incentive scorecard. How are you going to make sure you don't overshoot and cut off legitimate needs-based selling and relat
componenttext: Tim, I know it's early here, but maybe you could talk about what factors are you going to be balancing when you redesign the sales incentive scorecard. How are you going to make sure you don't overshoot and cut off legitimate needs-based selling and relationship building while also making sure you don't encourage the wrong behavior?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question, John. I think the focus is going to be first on, and this is a little bit high level, but on thinking about what are the drivers of developing those life-long relationships with our customers. It's about service, it's about conv
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question, John. I think the focus is going to be first on, and this is a little bit high level, but on thinking about what are the drivers of developing those life-long relationships with our customers. It's about service, it's about convenience. So think about our bankers being incented to provide good service. And so we'll be measuring that on an independent basis to think about our bankers being focused on helping our customers do more business but being measured on product usage and activity as opposed to individual product sales. And also about an overall growth in assets and balances. And also think about it being much more driven to a team approach as opposed to just on an individual basis. We think that, that is going to be successful. Mary and team are working on the specifics of that right now. And when we complete the analysis and they recommend the program, that's one of the other areas that we'll provide some transparency about.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up for John. On the net interest margin and net interest income, when we try to assess the impact of what a potential rate hike would do, one rate hike, it's hard to discern what happened after the December hike last time beca
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up for John. On the net interest margin and net interest income, when we try to assess the impact of what a potential rate hike would do, one rate hike, it's hard to discern what happened after the December hike last time because the first quarter, you had a few moving parts. What's your best guess of kind of what kind of help you would get to your NIM from one rate hike? And then what's the ongoing impact on NIM on the other side from TLAC issuance in terms of drag?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would -- the net number that I would look to for ease of modeling if we got 1 25 [ph] basis point move would be something on the order of $150 million per quarter in the first year. There's a lot going into that in terms of asset liability, mix, loan
componenttext: So I would -- the net number that I would look to for ease of modeling if we got 1 25 [ph] basis point move would be something on the order of $150 million per quarter in the first year. There's a lot going into that in terms of asset liability, mix, loan growth, deposit growth, TLAC issuance, et cetera. But that's a reasonable placeholder that accounts for the net.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Paul Miller with FBR Co.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Paul Miller with FBR Co.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relative to some of the shakeup you guys had in your executive leadership, has there been any thought to bring somebody from the outside? Because a lot of you guys have been with the bank for multiple, multiple years and to bring somebody from the outside
componenttext: Relative to some of the shakeup you guys had in your executive leadership, has there been any thought to bring somebody from the outside? Because a lot of you guys have been with the bank for multiple, multiple years and to bring somebody from the outside to give a fresh look of the culture.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a fair question. And it's one we've been getting asked. I think the board, by the changes that we've made over the last week and few weeks is comfortable with and very supportive of the management team. I think over the last few years really si
componenttext: Well, it's a fair question. And it's one we've been getting asked. I think the board, by the changes that we've made over the last week and few weeks is comfortable with and very supportive of the management team. I think over the last few years really since the financial crisis, we had a huge opportunity in 8 years ago to reset the entire team. And we selected the best folks that were available for all the roles. Since then, and one of the great things about the company has been how we've been able to attract many senior leaders from outside the company, not only in our business lines but also in many of our support functions, including Corporate Risk so that's how it really happened from my perspective.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then on the independent audit, is there any timeline for that? And did you disclose who is doing the audit?
componenttext: Yes. And then on the independent audit, is there any timeline for that? And did you disclose who is doing the audit?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's an investigation that's being spearheaded by Shearman & Sterling, which is working on behalf of the Board. It's independent and we don't have a date by which it's going to be finished. Hopefully, it'll be finished as soon as practical, but I th
componenttext: Well, it's an investigation that's being spearheaded by Shearman & Sterling, which is working on behalf of the Board. It's independent and we don't have a date by which it's going to be finished. Hopefully, it'll be finished as soon as practical, but I think independence and thoroughness is much more important than getting something done in a short period of time.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of the 115,000 accounts that were opened without authorization and charged a fee, how many customers did those 115,000 accounts reflect? And what's been your retention rate of those customers?
componenttext: Of the 115,000 accounts that were opened without authorization and charged a fee, how many customers did those 115,000 accounts reflect? And what's been your retention rate of those customers?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the customer count is somewhat lower than the incidence of the product count, at least with respect to the 1.5 million deposit accounts, which is the bigger number but the ones that couldn't be ruled out. That related to 1.1 million customers so i
componenttext: I think the customer count is somewhat lower than the incidence of the product count, at least with respect to the 1.5 million deposit accounts, which is the bigger number but the ones that couldn't be ruled out. That related to 1.1 million customers so it was sort of a 3:2 ratio there. So I'd say it's somewhat south of 100,000 customers for the 115,000 impacted accounts. And retention ratio. I don't have retention ratio at hand. It's not something that's independently being measured, at least not at this level.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I guess, some -- a follow-up. This is a long wind-up here but it's a little frustrating not getting that retention information. I think we want to know the customers that were impacted the most with your retention rate. I guess we can't really
componenttext: All right. I guess, some -- a follow-up. This is a long wind-up here but it's a little frustrating not getting that retention information. I think we want to know the customers that were impacted the most with your retention rate. I guess we can't really ask about the internal investigation, there's no time frame. We can't ask who knew what and when. We can't ask why it took so long to stop the problems. This is the first time we've had to ask a question of the call. We don't have Steve Sanger in this call. And so it's a long wind-up like I said. Maybe a little bit more on potential branch closings, Slide, I guess, 24, you talked about, it could allow you to review the branch footprint for consolidation opportunities. I mean, you have 6,000 branches and you're having success with digital delivery and it's exciting that is promoted into this new position. I'm sure look at that, but can you give us something concrete as it relates to all this? Maybe when you look at the new chapter, what the potential might be for efficiency improvements, especially if you're telling us the efficiencies should be elevated for some time?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, listen, I appreciate your question, and as one of the many stakeholders to Wells Fargo, I'm sorry that we have disappointed you. But we just spent 30 minutes talking about what's going on at the company and we've provided a lot of information. We pr
componenttext: Mike, listen, I appreciate your question, and as one of the many stakeholders to Wells Fargo, I'm sorry that we have disappointed you. But we just spent 30 minutes talking about what's going on at the company and we've provided a lot of information. We provided new slides that provide a tremendous amount of detail on some of the retail sales practices issue. And we've deliberately and diligently walked through the performance of all our businesses. And you know what, if that doesn't satisfy you, I'm sorry.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well maybe at next year's Investor Day, do you think we'll hear more about how you'll configure your branches and kind of the next stage of that?
componenttext: All right. Well maybe at next year's Investor Day, do you think we'll hear more about how you'll configure your branches and kind of the next stage of that?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh sure, absolutely. I mean, we talked about it at our last Investor Day, and that's one of the reasons why we want to accelerate the timing of our Investor Day because we want to provide increased transparency, which we've done today and we want to provi
componenttext: Oh sure, absolutely. I mean, we talked about it at our last Investor Day, and that's one of the reasons why we want to accelerate the timing of our Investor Day because we want to provide increased transparency, which we've done today and we want to provide more continuous updates as to how we're operating the company.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies and Company.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies and Company.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if we can just talk about the environment a little bit. Loan growth was okay, but certainly, we've seen this kind of air pocket on the commercial side a little bit from the industry perspective. And I'm wondering if you can just talk about
componenttext: I was wondering if we can just talk about the environment a little bit. Loan growth was okay, but certainly, we've seen this kind of air pocket on the commercial side a little bit from the industry perspective. And I'm wondering if you can just talk about what you guys are seeing in terms of commercial demand especially, and if you're seeing any just noted changes in terms of customer activity and whether you think that's either fleeting or whether you guys are taking a different view of extension of credit at all.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think overall in the wholesale businesses, as you said, every quarter is -- can be a little bit different in terms of loan growth. We didn't see any trends in any of our wholesale businesses that would cause us concern that Commercial Real Estate l
componenttext: Yes, I think overall in the wholesale businesses, as you said, every quarter is -- can be a little bit different in terms of loan growth. We didn't see any trends in any of our wholesale businesses that would cause us concern that Commercial Real Estate loans are going one way or as the base loans are going another. One of the reasons why our loan growth in the third quarter was -- in commercial wasn't as strong as in prior quarters is because our energy book declined by, I can't recall the exact figure, $1.5 billion to $2 billion. We're still very active in the energy industry, but it makes sense that if there's a bit of a decline there. We had a few kind of larger underwritings that either paid off or transformed into long-term debt or equity for our customers but nothing alarming from our perspective.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then as a follow-up, John, I noticed that the securities book was $390 billion at the end of the quarter. Looks like you're moving some of that liquidity maybe and also replacement of some of that loan growth. Can you just talk about the re
componenttext: All right. And then as a follow-up, John, I noticed that the securities book was $390 billion at the end of the quarter. Looks like you're moving some of that liquidity maybe and also replacement of some of that loan growth. Can you just talk about the reinvestment philosophy? What kind of stuff you're investing in? And are you able to find a good ROA, ROE on moving the book into securities at this time, given where rates are?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. While the first call on that liquidity would be the loans that we just talked about to the extent that there was incremental loan demand. We've -- versus how we've deployed liquidity in the past, we obviously have more of a bias toward things that q
componenttext: Sure. While the first call on that liquidity would be the loans that we just talked about to the extent that there was incremental loan demand. We've -- versus how we've deployed liquidity in the past, we obviously have more of a bias toward things that qualify for HQLA just because of the environment that we're living in for liquidity. So you've seen a lot of agency mortgage-backed securities. You've seen some treasuries, we actually got a program of late to be a little bit more active in Ginnie Mae securities because of their liquidity properties. We also have a portfolio of -- a smaller portfolio on the security side somewhat more credit sensitive, so corporates or CMBS, things like that, that we replenish every quarter as well. The returns are okay. And we have this lower for longer bias that makes us comfortable deploying capital in that way and liquidity in that way and the capital to withstand what happens if we're wrong about rates so we end up in a higher rate environment. But it's consistent with the approach that we've taken over the last couple of quarters. We paused in the first quarter while there was a real drop in both market volatility that gave rise to risk-free rates going as well as they have. But now in the second quarter and the third quarter, we've been back to converting cash into duration basically. Is that helpful?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Autonomous Research.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about overdraft charges. A few articles out there have kind of maybe asserted some of the opt-in processes were overzealous, let's call it, at the retail network. So is that something you've booked as part of your r
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about overdraft charges. A few articles out there have kind of maybe asserted some of the opt-in processes were overzealous, let's call it, at the retail network. So is that something you've booked as part of your review? And then we don't get a ton of history from the filings, but it is broken out and it seems like your overdraft was running about 12%, plus 12% year-over-year in terms of growth, which is a bit stronger than the industry. So separate from any of the practice what was driving kind of that overdraft fee growth?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. We saw some of the same reports that you did. And candidly, those were a little bit of a surprise. Having said that, like all facets of our Retail Banking business, we're going to -- we're going to review those. And to the extent there are an
componenttext: Sure, Brian. We saw some of the same reports that you did. And candidly, those were a little bit of a surprise. Having said that, like all facets of our Retail Banking business, we're going to -- we're going to review those. And to the extent there are any issues, we'll deal with them. But we're not aware today that there were a driver of overdraft income.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe on some of these new account production metrics, it's very helpful, I appreciate the disclosure. I'm assuming the average life of checking accounts and credit cards is pretty long. So is there like a rule of thumb translation you can
componenttext: Great. And then maybe on some of these new account production metrics, it's very helpful, I appreciate the disclosure. I'm assuming the average life of checking accounts and credit cards is pretty long. So is there like a rule of thumb translation you can give us, I mean, if the run rate of new accounts is down 25% for 6 months, let's say, is that a 1 percentage point headwind to balanced growth, 2 percentage points? I mean, how should we think about that in terms of thinking about balance growth all of equal [ph] over the next 2 [ph] years?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would separate that into credit cards, one, and deposit accounts, second. I think credit cards, it's all a bit tricky just because over the last few years, we've seen such growth in our credit card business in terms of penetration and our usage num
componenttext: Yes, I would separate that into credit cards, one, and deposit accounts, second. I think credit cards, it's all a bit tricky just because over the last few years, we've seen such growth in our credit card business in terms of penetration and our usage numbers have been good. But you can imagine a point where there -- if credit card growth is down a little bit, that in a year or so from now, that we could see some decline. But of course, that assumes that we don't make any other changes in our credit card products and our offerings, how we interact with customers and the like. So don't have a great rule of thumb there. And again, as it relates to the deposit accounts, and John jump in here if you feel differently, we're so new into the impact. And what we tried to do in the expanded disclosure is show you the decline in a monthly basis but also give you a sense of what the impact was on the total base. I think that's how I would think about it, and I appreciate that you appreciated our increased disclosure.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the only thing I would add is not all deposit accounts are equal in terms of their contribution to deposit balances, right? Here, we have deposits growing by $6 billion when we have new accounts not opening as quickly.
componenttext: I guess the only thing I would add is not all deposit accounts are equal in terms of their contribution to deposit balances, right? Here, we have deposits growing by $6 billion when we have new accounts not opening as quickly.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Brian, that's another reason why we want to continue to provide enhanced disclosure because we want to make sure that you're comfortable with how any of the headwinds we're facing right now are affecting the business.
componenttext: But Brian, that's another reason why we want to continue to provide enhanced disclosure because we want to make sure that you're comfortable with how any of the headwinds we're facing right now are affecting the business.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016

componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the -- I guess, my question gets back to, sadly to the account issue. But can you describe if there's been any review of interaction, the communications about these kinds of issues with the board? And just sort to get to my follow-up, what I'
componenttext: I think that the -- I guess, my question gets back to, sadly to the account issue. But can you describe if there's been any review of interaction, the communications about these kinds of issues with the board? And just sort to get to my follow-up, what I'm really wondering is if this raises the risk of qualitative review as it relates to CCAR or any other kind of regulatory action.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take the first part of that question. As I mentioned, the board has engaged Shearman & Sterling to do an investigation retail sales product issues and other matters. And we want to be very respectful of their process, and we want that process to
componenttext: So let me take the first part of that question. As I mentioned, the board has engaged Shearman & Sterling to do an investigation retail sales product issues and other matters. And we want to be very respectful of their process, and we want that process to be taken seriously and to be viewed independently. So I don't want to comment on the specifics of how they're going to go about their review. But we look forward to...

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to interrupt but I guess I'm getting to the issue of it seems like at least from the press reports, this issue went on for several years before management made the board aware, and I'm just wondering if that issue has been addressed.
componenttext: Sorry to interrupt but I guess I'm getting to the issue of it seems like at least from the press reports, this issue went on for several years before management made the board aware, and I'm just wondering if that issue has been addressed.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, here's how I would answer that, and that is that there's going to be an independent review. And I think it would be appropriate to wait for the independent review as opposed to jumping to the conclusion about what media might think. I don't mean to
componenttext: Well, here's how I would answer that, and that is that there's going to be an independent review. And I think it would be appropriate to wait for the independent review as opposed to jumping to the conclusion about what media might think. I don't mean to be disrespectful to the media but I don't know if they have all the facts. And the review will look it at all the facts and will make some recommendations, I'm sure.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: You created a new role on the board of Vice Chair, and you put Elizabeth Duke in that role and appointed her there. She has an extensive amount of industry and regulatory experience. You created that role for a purpose. Can you frame that a little bit for
componenttext: You created a new role on the board of Vice Chair, and you put Elizabeth Duke in that role and appointed her there. She has an extensive amount of industry and regulatory experience. You created that role for a purpose. Can you frame that a little bit for us and let us understand how you expect to leverage her in that role?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Marty, I want to be very respectful of the fact that neither John or I created that role, the board did. Having said that, we couldn't -- first, we have a terrific board. It's diverse. It's diverse in terms of the types of industries that they've
componenttext: Sure. So Marty, I want to be very respectful of the fact that neither John or I created that role, the board did. Having said that, we couldn't -- first, we have a terrific board. It's diverse. It's diverse in terms of the types of industries that they've been involved in, their experience, and we just couldn't be more pleased with the quality of that board. In particular, having both Steve Sanger and Betsy being -- Betsy Duke being willing to step up into these roles is, I think, absolutely the right decision that the board should be making in these circumstances. Separating the CEO and Chairman role is something that we've done in the past. But again, in particular to Betsy, to have somebody like that with not only industry experience but also regulatory experience in this environment to provide assistance for Steve is exactly what's needed.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then not Monday Morning Quarterback or rehash what you've done in the past, but Tim, I really wanted to ask you has -- what, in this experience, has changed the way you think about the role of CEO as you now assume it and Wells Fargo as a company or a
componenttext: And then not Monday Morning Quarterback or rehash what you've done in the past, but Tim, I really wanted to ask you has -- what, in this experience, has changed the way you think about the role of CEO as you now assume it and Wells Fargo as a company or a culture? And what is the key takeaway? Whenever you go through these extreme crises, there's always something that you learn that will make the company better as you move forward. What have you learned that you're going to now take to the -- your new role and be able to push forward?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Marty, that's a great question. And by the way, don't apologize for being a Monday Morning Quarterback. Candidly, we deserve that and we're used to it over the last few weeks. I also want to preface my remarks by saying I've been in this role for le
componenttext: Well, Marty, that's a great question. And by the way, don't apologize for being a Monday Morning Quarterback. Candidly, we deserve that and we're used to it over the last few weeks. I also want to preface my remarks by saying I've been in this role for less than 48 hours, and I want you to have high expectations for me but I actually want to make sure that those are a bit tempered. When I think about the retail sales practices issue we've had at the company, I wish that the business had escalated the issue sooner. I wish when the business escalated the issue that while the senior management team did a lot in response, I wish we could have done more. And I highlight that because I think that one of the lessons that I've learned but one of the lessons the entire company has learned and one of the reasons that we're organized the way we are today and we're making many of the changes that we talked about are that we've got to escalate issues whenever they occur within the company's owner, we've got to deal with them sooner, and we've got to make sure that to the extent that they have any impact on our customers, that we deal with that, impact as quickly as we can. So it's about escalation and it's about speed and dealing with challenges and also dealing with opportunities as they come, right?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you feel that in that vein, being a high performer and being looked at as a high-quality bank for so long, created some blinders that may be those blunders now have been taken off in your, like you're saying, reacting and moving quicker at this point?
componenttext: Do you feel that in that vein, being a high performer and being looked at as a high-quality bank for so long, created some blinders that may be those blunders now have been taken off in your, like you're saying, reacting and moving quicker at this point?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know. I mean, it's a fair question. I don't know if it created blinders. But again, the fact of the matter is we should have escalated these issues sooner, and we should have dealt with them more quickly than we did. So to the extent that som
componenttext: Yes, I don't know. I mean, it's a fair question. I don't know if it created blinders. But again, the fact of the matter is we should have escalated these issues sooner, and we should have dealt with them more quickly than we did. So to the extent that some of our prior success impacted that, so be it. I can assure you that we've talked about what you just described a lot, and we're going to make sure that, that doesn't create a blinder now or in the future.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Chris Kotowski with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Chris Kotowski with Oppenheimer.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I never thought I'd ask you about this page via your press release again, but I'm looking at Page 31 at the accreteable yield, which usually wiggles and wobbles by $100 million or $200 million a quarter, and all of a sudden, the expected cash flows are do
componenttext: I never thought I'd ask you about this page via your press release again, but I'm looking at Page 31 at the accreteable yield, which usually wiggles and wobbles by $100 million or $200 million a quarter, and all of a sudden, the expected cash flows are down by almost $5 billion. So can you say what happened there? And does that -- is that a headwind to net interest income going forward?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm glad you asked. I wasn't sure whether anybody was going to get there. So the accreteable yield balance was down $4 billion in the quarter. It stands at about, I think, $11.2 billion right now. So what's happened here is that prepayments have sped up.
componenttext: I'm glad you asked. I wasn't sure whether anybody was going to get there. So the accreteable yield balance was down $4 billion in the quarter. It stands at about, I think, $11.2 billion right now. So what's happened here is that prepayments have sped up. We've reached a point where a lot of these borrowers have gotten themselves in the money for refis because of the path of HPI, and we're experiencing and modeling faster cash flows as a result of that. And so frankly in the near term, I think we'll see an increase to interest income as more of that comes through, but what it means is those loans will be outstanding for as long as you might have previously predicted because they will be refined.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- and -- so that would be elevated accretion to net interest income than the next 4 -- couple of quarters, whatever, as you experience that?
componenttext: So -- and -- so that would be elevated accretion to net interest income than the next 4 -- couple of quarters, whatever, as you experience that?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a headwind in future quarters after that? Okay. And the other thing I was wondering is how should we think about the impact of the settlement on op risk RWAs? I mean, obviously, the financial impact is minor, but the impact on your company has be
componenttext: And then a headwind in future quarters after that? Okay. And the other thing I was wondering is how should we think about the impact of the settlement on op risk RWAs? I mean, obviously, the financial impact is minor, but the impact on your company has been big in terms of management and press and reputation and so on. And so how quickly does it all get factored in? And any light you can shed on and whatever the algorithm is?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's tough to say because the chapter hasn't -- the middle chapters haven't been written of what the op risk outcome is. I mean, we know what the settlement was. We've got a variety of legal matters that we have to attend to, all of which will factor i
componenttext: So it's tough to say because the chapter hasn't -- the middle chapters haven't been written of what the op risk outcome is. I mean, we know what the settlement was. We've got a variety of legal matters that we have to attend to, all of which will factor into a future view of what the total op risk experience is from it. So at the margin would be increasing. I think I mentioned earlier, in CCAR, our own stress analysis, we concoct and imagine outsized op risk outcomes to demonstrate that we've got the capital and earnings power to overcome them. And the magnitude of what we're talking about here frankly is, while it's significant, is modest in comparison to what you can imagine in stress, both in our own scenario as well as in CCAR. And of course, what it means from the regulators perspective is they think about our op risk capacity in the future is up to them. But it will have an increase at the margin. It doesn't have a material increase in the moment because the numbers, as you say, have not been that big on the scale of Wells Fargo's balance sheet and earnings power so far. But it's a headwind in op risk. We've been fortunate to have had modest op risk outcomes relative to the GSIB peer group over the CCAR era, and this feels different because of the severity of the reputational arm that's been created.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question just on, easy one first, on the long-term debt. I know you said it went up based on the TLAC issuance, but since you also have debt that you put on related to the GE deals for prefunding those deals that was Is that still on the balance s
componenttext: A quick question just on, easy one first, on the long-term debt. I know you said it went up based on the TLAC issuance, but since you also have debt that you put on related to the GE deals for prefunding those deals that was Is that still on the balance sheet or did you put that back this quarter as well?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's still on the balance sheet so it is portable, and it's FHLB type of financing so it shows up as longer-term debt but -- and you can see that on Page 15, I think, of today's deck. So still in place. Now of course, we're just using it as part of t
componenttext: Yes, it's still on the balance sheet so it is portable, and it's FHLB type of financing so it shows up as longer-term debt but -- and you can see that on Page 15, I think, of today's deck. So still in place. Now of course, we're just using it as part of the general liability structure overall, and we'll use it as long as we think it's a good component of this deck.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the slide where you're monitoring the customer activity in the Retail Banking, you note that consumer checking account opens were down 25% [ph] year-on-year, credit card applications down 20% year-on-year. But if you start to annualize t
componenttext: Okay. And then on the slide where you're monitoring the customer activity in the Retail Banking, you note that consumer checking account opens were down 25% [ph] year-on-year, credit card applications down 20% year-on-year. But if you start to annualize those numbers, you talked very much if you think about the credit card applications. That would be down, on a full year basis, down 12% year-on-year relative to the total outstanding. So I mean, is there a way to quantify what that monthly impact was as it relates to revenue? I'm sure like not all applications actually get opened, but...

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the waterfall there is that applications may or may not become approvals, and approvals may or may not become activated cards, and activated cards have to become utilized, and utilized cards become balances and balances accrue interest. So there's a lo
componenttext: So the waterfall there is that applications may or may not become approvals, and approvals may or may not become activated cards, and activated cards have to become utilized, and utilized cards become balances and balances accrue interest. So there's a lot of steps that have to be gone through before applications have an impact on either assets or revenue. One of the reasons for showing this is to help people understand what the immediate impact is and then to roll it forward, so we can see whether annualizing that September number is really the right way to approach it. September obviously was the first month, the month where we pulled back on marketing, it's the month when our team members were probably the most uncertain in terms of what the go-forward model's going to be as we pivot towards service. It's the month when our customers and prospects are first reflecting their real dissatisfaction with Wells Fargo, all those things put together, and those are going to change in different ways as we roll it forward. So it's the installed base that drives the P&L results and that is where it is. And Tim mentioned that we're going to roll this forward probably during the quarter so people can see whether October looks like September and November looks like October, and then we can start to build a projectable impact on the trend. Hopefully, that's helpful

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is.
componenttext: Yes, it is.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, congratulations even though [indiscernible].
componenttext: Tim, congratulations even though [indiscernible].

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Me too.
componenttext: Me too.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for both of you. You took a charge in the second quarter for CFPB settlement, which was announced on September 8. Why no disclosure on the financial filings? And are you planning to change anything as you think about that aspect as you look forwa
componenttext: Question for both of you. You took a charge in the second quarter for CFPB settlement, which was announced on September 8. Why no disclosure on the financial filings? And are you planning to change anything as you think about that aspect as you look forward?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a tricky one because we certainly account for these items when they become known or probable and estimable under GAAP. But separately, we're also -- these are also part of confidential supervisory information that limitation on how much you can ta
componenttext: So it's a tricky one because we certainly account for these items when they become known or probable and estimable under GAAP. But separately, we're also -- these are also part of confidential supervisory information that limitation on how much you can talk about while you're in the middle of a negotiation with the regulator. Now they can talk about whatever they chose to and they do sometimes, and other times, they wait until it ends. So we think about the circumstances in the moment. We obviously would love to be disclosed help people understand what's going on. We're certainly taking the charges, but we need to take the charge but were not alone in that discussion, and usually, the circumstances are governed by, in the case of our regulator, the regulator. So that's how I think about that.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So without giving us the amount, you couldn't even disclose some of the facts or the existence of those discussions?
componenttext: So without giving us the amount, you couldn't even disclose some of the facts or the existence of those discussions?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Vivek, the way that I would think about it is that this stems from the lawsuit that the city of LA filed a year before that. And so there was -- there were issues that we were dealing with. But as John said we've got to be very careful and respectfu
componenttext: Well, Vivek, the way that I would think about it is that this stems from the lawsuit that the city of LA filed a year before that. And so there was -- there were issues that we were dealing with. But as John said we've got to be very careful and respectful of what we disclose in terms of conversations that we have with our regulators. And that's really important. And so the short answer is we follow appropriate policies, procedures, rules and disclosure requirements.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Separate question sort of linked to all the [indiscernible] that's going on, Tim. As a GSIB bank [indiscernible] now with all of these happening increase yield [ph] Does that have any bearing on how you think about asset size as one metric? You're almost
componenttext: Separate question sort of linked to all the [indiscernible] that's going on, Tim. As a GSIB bank [indiscernible] now with all of these happening increase yield [ph] Does that have any bearing on how you think about asset size as one metric? You're almost $1.95 trillion, the third-largest bank Citi [indiscernible] companies to [indiscernible] and allow Is that something that is factored into how [indiscernible] too big or what does it mean longer term?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a fair question. I think and John jump in, we're focused less on size because size is ultimately determined by our customers. It's not necessarily determined by us. And we wanted our team members with the right incentives and have them work toge
componenttext: Yes, it's a fair question. I think and John jump in, we're focused less on size because size is ultimately determined by our customers. It's not necessarily determined by us. And we wanted our team members with the right incentives and have them work together and provide good advice and service to our customers and make sure that we've got great products out there. That's what's going to drive our size. Having said that, we need to make sure that as we think about our return, so putting the lens that you might use, which we do all the time, are we getting and providing the appropriate returns for our investors based upon our size? That's how we think about it. Having said that, we've looked at across the company and you've seen us exit some businesses that we believe would not provide us with as stronger return as they might provide another owner. We sold our crop business, we sold our HSA business and so on. And because we appreciate in this environment and given the amount of liquidity and capital that we have, that we've got to be very mindful in terms of how we deploy our assets.

componenttext: Well, I wouldn't jump to a conclusion about whether there's a transparency issue or not. But that's -- I'm sorry, Nancy, I want to be very respectful to the board because that's the board's decision.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My second question would be this. I mean, obviously, there are going to be some near-term issues here, not only retaining customers but in attracting new ones. And I'm wondering if there is any thought being given to deposit pricing or fees, et cete
componenttext: Okay. My second question would be this. I mean, obviously, there are going to be some near-term issues here, not only retaining customers but in attracting new ones. And I'm wondering if there is any thought being given to deposit pricing or fees, et cetera, as one of the levers to attract new clients.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nancy, all good idea is in this company around the table. We've got an impressive management team. Whenever a company, and it's certainly the case for us, is faced with these kinds of challenges, it's absolutely appropriate to step back and think about al
componenttext: Nancy, all good idea is in this company around the table. We've got an impressive management team. Whenever a company, and it's certainly the case for us, is faced with these kinds of challenges, it's absolutely appropriate to step back and think about all aspects of how we provide product and service and convenience to our customers. And we certainly are thinking about price. Having said that, that when you think about the driver of our company, one of the drivers for our company for decades is building that life-long relationship that's not based on price. So could we make some changes in our pricing of certain products, deposit or otherwise? Sure, we could but I would not expect us to lead with price.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just ask an add-on to that, I mean, obviously your employees have really been put through the ringer through this whole process. Is there any thought about additional compensation or bonuses this year or something just as a way of say
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just ask an add-on to that, I mean, obviously your employees have really been put through the ringer through this whole process. Is there any thought about additional compensation or bonuses this year or something just as a way of saying, "We're sorry"?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think saying that we put our team members through the ringer is an understatement. I really do. I really do, especially our team members in -- on our Retail Banking platform. But it's throughout the company. We want to make sure that we retain the best
componenttext: I think saying that we put our team members through the ringer is an understatement. I really do. I really do, especially our team members in -- on our Retail Banking platform. But it's throughout the company. We want to make sure that we retain the best people that we can. And we think we offer a very competitive set of compensation investments. We talked a little bit about that on one of the slides. But we appreciate that we've got to re-recruit our team in this kind of environment and all ideas are on the table.

componenttext: I just want to follow up on some of the -- in regards to your comments around the expenses and the efficiency ratio, and you're saying it's going to be elevated and you said it was going to be elevated or on the higher end of the 55% to 59% range into 2016. Are you now saying that, that range is no longer valid, and longer term going into 2017, you might above the efficiency ratio range? How should we think about that?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: You should think about it as an annual range. This quarter, we popped up above it but it's still a good annual range. And if we start thinking that's not, then we'll telegraph that to people. It's hard to be more specific. The operational or compliance-re
componenttext: You should think about it as an annual range. This quarter, we popped up above it but it's still a good annual range. And if we start thinking that's not, then we'll telegraph that to people. It's hard to be more specific. The operational or compliance-related issues are one set of costs that may be can be modeled in the near term. But to the extent that we've got lumpy operational losses to drive it up, those are just harder to predict and they'll happen when they happen. But we will -- if we think we're -- the band is no longer the right band, then we'll tell you that.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when we think about the spend on marketing and compliance, are you expecting that to be offset by the potential to have branch closures or reductions in your branch costs in order to keep expenses under control due to other areas? Or how sh
componenttext: Okay. And then when we think about the spend on marketing and compliance, are you expecting that to be offset by the potential to have branch closures or reductions in your branch costs in order to keep expenses under control due to other areas? Or how should we think about the puts and takes around the expense number?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't tie the 2 together and I certainly wouldn't be focused on branch closures. I mean, what we've talked about and again, I reflect back on how we described our branch platform at Investor Day, that we continue to update it all the time. We mo
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't tie the 2 together and I certainly wouldn't be focused on branch closures. I mean, what we've talked about and again, I reflect back on how we described our branch platform at Investor Day, that we continue to update it all the time. We move branches around, we open new branches, we combine branches, we may close a few. I think this year, in fact, there's going to be a reduction unrelated to what we've talked about here. But as John described, we got to look at our expenses, and we have been looking at our expenses for some period of time to be able to keep the efficiency ratio within the range even though it's going to -- it's at the upper end of the range because we need to invest not only in compliance, we've got to invest in technology and bringing out new products and cyber defense and all of the above.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another thing, Kevin, is as it relates to other people have asked today with regard to that, whatever might happen on the branch network side of things, that's -- that doesn't necessarily give you an immediate lift. If you're thinking about today's elevat
componenttext: Another thing, Kevin, is as it relates to other people have asked today with regard to that, whatever might happen on the branch network side of things, that's -- that doesn't necessarily give you an immediate lift. If you're thinking about today's elevated compliance costs or today's elevated marketing costs, if we're making moves on physical distribution side of our business, that creates benefits in year 2, year 3, year 4 but it's not really paying an immediate offset. So as Tim said, I wouldn't think about those as offsetting leverage.

componenttext: Do you think you can stay within your target if rates were to remain flat from where they are right now?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the way that range was constructed was with our expectation for rates, which is practically flat. But for example, if we get a 25 basis point move in December, that wouldn't be unreasonable, and that's essentially baked in to be in that range. If we
componenttext: Well, the way that range was constructed was with our expectation for rates, which is practically flat. But for example, if we get a 25 basis point move in December, that wouldn't be unreasonable, and that's essentially baked in to be in that range. If we stay flat, we're not that far off from that [indiscernible] If we had a big move up in rates, which I think is highly unlikely, then that would probably move us down to the range. I think we've said that before.

componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up with -- on Marty's question. Tim, the response seemed largely tactical. And so I guess, as far as thinking about changes that your leadership might mean, does that mean that your view on the strategic approach versus prior leaders
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up with -- on Marty's question. Tim, the response seemed largely tactical. And so I guess, as far as thinking about changes that your leadership might mean, does that mean that your view on the strategic approach versus prior leadership is largely unchanged? And it's certainly true that you haven't been in the seat for very long, but the idea that you would be taking over is certainly something that wasn't out of the blue. So I'm sure you had some ideas coming in here.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I have lots of ideas but candidly, I'll be a lot more nervous if I came out with some new strategic plan for Wells Fargo in 48 hours. That would be pretty dangerous from my perspective. But look, the calm -- when I think about the company that I joi
componenttext: Well, I have lots of ideas but candidly, I'll be a lot more nervous if I came out with some new strategic plan for Wells Fargo in 48 hours. That would be pretty dangerous from my perspective. But look, the calm -- when I think about the company that I joined 29 years ago, it's so different today. My guess is that Wells Fargo is going to be different 5 years from now, 10 years from now and 15 years from now. You know what, I hope it is because by changing and adapting to the environment we're in, that's one of the reasons why we've had a history of success, notwithstanding the last month or so, correct? I mean, the last month or so has been a real challenge as we talked about on the call today and I'm sure we'll continue to talk about for a while. But we've made some important announcements this week. Again, you might call them tactical. I think they're actually in the strategic band. The creation of a new business line, the elevation of some new senior leaders in our Wholesale Banking and our Community Banking business as well as Consumer Lending. They are going to bring some new ideas. So that's a fair point that's probably all bit more tactical than strategic, but over time, you'll see some updates, and we'll talk about those over the next few months. And I'm sure we'll talk about some of that at Investor Day next year.

Okay. Sorry, go ahead.

componenttext: So a different direction here for the second question. One of your warehouse competitors has come out and confirmed the recent stories on their policies for dealing with the rule. Have you finalized your policies and can you tell us any details about those?

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're -- this is John. We're still in the process of refining the overall implementation approach to be compliant with the rules. I think we're still going to continue to approach every client relationship with an emphasis on every client having a cust
componenttext: So we're -- this is John. We're still in the process of refining the overall implementation approach to be compliant with the rules. I think we're still going to continue to approach every client relationship with an emphasis on every client having a customized plan that guides their investment activity. We're going to emphasize advisory solutions and continue to offer a traditional brokerage for certain clients of it includes self-directed options also, and you we'll be sharing more details as a get closer to implementation. I think with each ensuing quarter between now and later in '17, you should expect to hear a little bit more about the specifics of the implementation, but we haven't reached the same conclusion and the same time frame as the competitor I think you're referring to.

headline: Wells Fargo & Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2016

componenttext: Thank you. I know it's been a busy morning for everybody and our call has been a little bit longer than normal. But I really want to thank all of you for your thoughtful questions. The discussion has been incredibly helpful for both John and me, and we look forward to continuing to provide additional disclosure to you as we move through the quarter. And we thank you for your interest in Wells Fargo.
